number of helpful: 290 of 385 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												To preface this review, I have beat the game. This review is not out of frustration for not being able to accomplish that, but it is out of frustration from the game in general.For a match 3 game the concept is novel, adding a requirement of matching specific tiles to progress.Unfortunately once the novelty wears off, it becomes a chore. And the novelty will wear off, because the game is stacked against you in multiple ways, and requires you to lose repeatedly to complete tasks and buy upgrades (which soon become an artificial barrier to gameplay) before winning it even becomes possible.The main barrier to fun in the game is the manner of losing - not the inevitability, as with Tetris, but the speed at which it can happen. Every obstacle requires a specific type of match - attacks or keys - and the game can at whim decide to deprive you of these, leaving you helpless to do anything but wait until defeat.Other problems with the control system compound this. For instance, sliding the tiles is not well designed. If you click a tile, it can only slide by the first direction the mouse moves. So if you want to drag a tile upwards but your mouse moves a LITTLE to the left first, your tiles will try moving left and right instead. You can try again while the mouse button is held down, but you've lost that time.The matching detection is not great either. When you line or nearly line up a match, their tiles illuminate, however when you let go the tile you're moving can fit to an adjacent space, meaning the match does not occur and you have to start again. Once more, this costs time.The game needs resource management - trying to keep a healthy number of attack tiles and keys on the board at all times to be ready for any obstacles that arrive, but a couple of things ruin this as a concept and make the game even less fun.The monsters - particularly boss class monsters - require a LOT of matches and items to defeat, during which time you're losing time AND they hit you which also costs a nasty chunk of time. It goes without saying that despite the whole upgrade system, matching attack tiles is just not effective enough to keep the game balanced.The game can and does throw numerous amounts of the same obstacles at you consecutively, such as two chests, a door and then another chest. Even if you kept a healthy number of keys available at the start of this, you probably won't have enough to get through it all which leads to a lot of lost time and defeat. The same applies to multiple tough monsters.Matching tiles or using an item JUST before you arrive at an obstacle will cause it to be wasted. There's no tolerance whatsoever. This can lead to situations where you're not blocked by an obstacle, and too afraid to do anything because you don't want to lose the matches you can see available to you. This is contrary to the game's advertised element.Finally, when you match tiles, more appear which can result in combos. Normally in this kind of game these are desirable, but in this game they can and will punish you by decimating a resource you can see yourself needing soon - for instance, if you're fighting a monster with a chest behind it, a few keys may fall in during the fight, matching with the ones already on the board and severely depleting the keys. Then when you win the fight you won't be able to deal with the chest.Furthermore, when newly-fallen tiles create combos, this takes time during which you are unable to slide any tiles to make more matches. This results in awkward situations where you can see multiple matches you want to make but are unable to do so because a useless combo is ongoing and killing you in the process.You do get a very limited number of items, but most of the time an item does not even clear one of its respective obstacles. After a few hours of play to finally be able to challenge for the game's namesake 10,000,000 points (yes, you need to play for a few hours before winning a game even becomes a possibility), key items will not be enough to open a three-lock chest or door, and you will need at least three damage items to defeat a single monster.This game had promise, but its execution is disastrous. Its visuals and music are very fun for a few hours, but they do not last the extended periods of time demanded of you when the game becomes an unfair and repetitive grind.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												10000000 is a game that mixes the match-3 genre with an RPG angle. Now, it's not as enjoyable as the Puzzle Quest games but the game is not a complete trainwreck either. Despite the horrible controls (or morel like 'control' - it's mouse only and 'slide'-based, naturally intended for a smartphone device), it can serve you a bit of fun for a couple of hours. However, if you're out to get all of the achievements then you might be in for a long and painful grind. This is due to the very annoying RNG.All the negativity aside, let's get more into how the game works. You start out with a simple character, trapped in a place with barred up doors. You want to break free from this prison, but to do so, you must get a 10 000 000 score. Simple, right? Well, not really. Your toon is weak and in order to become stronger and advance then you need to gather supplies and gold. How do you do that? Well, that's where the core of the game comes in! You will need to arm yourself and venture into the dungeons! At first, you'll see the familiar match 3 board and you'll start to match tiles as you would in any type of game like this. Soon you will notice that you're not only meant to match them, you're meant to match certain tiles at certain times. Your toon will encounter foes with different abilities and weaknesses, knowing when to match the sword or the staff tiles might save you a lot of trouble here! There are also locks on chests and doors that you need to open by matching keys. Sometimes you will gain an item or a consumable by opening chests, but also if you match the chests on the tile board. These you can use to help you progress in the dungeons. Then there are the wood and stones that you need to upgrade the different shops.I had a lot of fun with the game in the beginning, especially when it felt like you made progress. Each new rank you unlock is a higher difficulty, and with each ranks there are several challenges to complete that grants you various bonuses. However, when you've reached the highest rank and completed all of the bonuses then the game kind of loses its potential. It takes a lot of luck and patience to even reach a score of 10 million, in any rank. I managed to 100% the game after nearly 13 hours of playtime. I've read about people who still hasn't been able to even after 30 hours, so keep this in mind if you're looking for an easy game to get perfect.Despite all the flaws and lack of fun end game I enjoyed it when I didn't feel too stressed out. The further you get, the quicker you need to be to match the tiles. You need to be able to notice when the border of your board turns red (encounters/events) or green (when your toon is mainly walking) and adapt to this in the best way possible. It takes time getting used to how the game functions, especially when it comes to matching the tiles by sliding the columns and rows. It can be extremely frustrating at times and I wish the developer had thought about this when porting the game to PC. It's already a challenging game and believe me, being defeated just because you weren't able to align the tiles perfectly due to whatever or any reason is just flat out aggrivating.I can recommend it if you like casual games that are a bit of a challenge. 10000000 is a challenge, both physically and mentally. In a good or bad way? Well, a bit of both to be honest.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												A surprisingly fun game, 10,000,000 gave me more far more enjoyment than I had expected when I initially purchased it for a few dollars.  Though the game is primarily a Match-Three, every single type that you match provides an effect that drastically alters your current encounter.  Match three (or more for an increased effect) swords, for example, and you'll unleash a physical attack; match three magic wands, you'll cast a magical attack; match three keys, you'll unlock a treasure chest or door, etc.The game is quite challenging, though each time you run through a dungeon path you'll acquire gold, experience, and items that will aid you in future runs.  Gold can be used to upgrade your equipment (swords, staves, shields, armor, etc.) by choosing a specific trait such as the sharpness of your sword (critical chance) or the material that it is made out of (base damage).  Experience can be used to purchase training upgrades which enhance abilities such as your lockpicking skills and increasing damage against certain enemy types.All in all, it's a cheap game with a good amount of fun to be had as long as you keep that in mind.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												I was quite drawn to 10,000,000 because of the promise it showed in mixing RPG and puzzle elements. While the game delivered less depth than the concept seemed to allow for, I still got a very fast-paced, addictive, and satisfying puzzler. It was cumbersome using a mouse to play a game that was clearly designed with touch screens in mind, but the gameplay was enjoyable enough at its core to ease that pain most of the time. The music was catchy, and the variety of things to level up provided enough incentive to make it through most of the game. What I most appreciated was the fact that you're unlikely to brute force your way to the 10,000,000 point goal by simply grinding enough to level everything. Success is ultimately the result of strategy, speed, and good fortune, which was refreshing after the way so many other smartphone ports that have made it to this platform just hand victory to the player after a significant enough investment of time and virtual currency. It's unlikely that you'll want to revisit this one after beating it, but the asking price is very reasonable for a game of 10,000,000's overall quality.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												10 Million is, simply put, a match 3 game. While it boasts "rpg elements," they are extremely minimal and 99% of the game is spent on the puzzle board. If that's your kind of game, then look no further. This title is best suited for casual gamers.ProsCozy pixel graphicsEntirely mouse controlled, fast response"RPG lite" element that allows you to spend resources to upgrade damage, defense, and other perksObjectives, or in-game tasks, are used to gate progression, giving you a sense of achievement.The alchemy lab potions allow you to customize your gameplay further to help you reach your goalsConsOnly 2 or 3 tracks of music become quickly repetitive, chiptunes can be distracting for concentrationThe pixel graphics practically hid upgrade button at the top of the room window, making me work a lot harder halfway through the game. I wish it had been more visible.Item use is finicky, meaning, if you are racing through and click an item before the character stops in front of the enemy, the item is wasted. This was a source of much frustration in speed runs.The last two achievements require you to hit 10 million on lower difficulties, and Jose especially becomes somewhat luck based to spawn a "clear path" to goal.Low replayability after game completion outside of achievementsShort game overall, only a couple hours to clearA word of advice to achievement hunters: You must exit the game for the achievements to register. Hopefully this saves you extra runs thinking you didn't hit the score achievements.Happy matching!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												10,000,000 is an arcade match-3 RPG with base management mechanics. Now, that may sound schizophrenic, but all the features actually mold together quite well to create a strange but fun experience. The gameplay consists mostly of dragging rows of cubes in order to match 3 of a certain type of cube, thereby helping you pass whatever obstacle you are currently faced with. Unfortunately, the game often gives you tons of whatever you need the least of at a certain time, leading to quite a lot of frustration. I remember one run in which I started out with a ton of keys.“Yeah!” I thought. “I’ll be totally set for this run!”I was then presented with about  10 or 15 obstacles in a row that required keys, and I ran out about halfway through and had to simply bide my time until the one match that I needed came along, using up all of my special items and powerups in the process. Now, whether that was built into the engine or I just have the worst luck in the world remains to be seen, but that kind of thing happens extremely frequently.The gameplay sometimes gets as annoying as the music (an extremely loud 8-bit tune in an endless loop), with the aforementioned situation of having everything except the one thing that you need providing nearly endless frustration. The goal of the game is to get 10,000,000 points in a single run, because apparently that will help you somehow escape the prison you are in. While in a run, you can collect special items for use in a pinch, as well as building materials, gold, and experience. You can use the building materials to fix and upgrade your base. What benefit do base upgrades give? They help you waste all your gold and XP getting upgrades for your equipment.Later on in the game, the price of training skills and getting upgrades becomes completely outrageous, whilst you are left sitting on a huge pile of wood and stone with nothing to spend it on. One thing I did like about the game was the difficulty curve. As you gather more points and complete objectives, you rank up and are forced to face harder and harder monsters. Thankfully, this gives the game a natural flow. Every time you rank up, the super-hard boss monsters that used to always kill you before you could get any matches in become commonplace grunts.Overall, 10,000,000 is a fun game, and it is definitely worth 5 bucks for the hours of gameplay you will undoubtedly get from it. While many players like me will ragequit often, you’ll always be coming back for more. I hope we can see a more polished and less frustrating sequel sometime in the future.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												+ Great "match 3" mechanics+ Pretty good chip-tunes and pixel art (if you're into that sort of art)+ Delivers the "just one more turn" mindset+ Equipment upgrading mechanics- Very repetitive and has little to offer- Relies on pure luck for extremely high scores- Obviously a mobile port, even though it is ported well for PC10,000,000 is a "match 3" type puzzler with a "retro" art style with chip-tune music and pixel graphics by EightyEightGames. As with most games of this type, you don't need many words to describe how you play.The core gameplay consists of sliding rows and columns of various icons so that three or more align, making the aligned icons disappear and making new ones fall out of the top to replace them. The spin that 10,000,000 has to offer is that you're a prisoner of a dungeon, and you must score, well, 10 million points to get out. You earn points by killing monsters and opening doors and chests, by matching staffs and swords, or keys, respectively. Matching backpacks gives a chance of earning items, which you can then use to kill monsters, to give you more time in the dungeon or to open chests and doors. There are also wood and stone icons, which give you those as a resource that stays the same between playthroughs. There are two other, similarly working resources: experience and gold, which are earned by killing monsters and opening chests. Once you run out of time in the dungeon, you return to the main hub where you can use the resources you've amassed to upgrade your statistics in rooms that can be upgraded. To progress through the dungeon you must complete quests such as "match x amount of y tiles", or "make x amount of triple matches". Eventually, a quest involving scoring a set amount of points during a round appears, and upon completing the quest, you gain a new rank and may now start the next run further in the dungeon.Now, that looks like a ton of words, but that is literally all the game has to offer. There is nothing else in this game (apart from the ending, which I won't spoil, but trust me when I say that I wouldn't need many more words to describe what happens after getting 10,000,000 points).The game sports a "retro" feel to complement the mechanics, which works fine. The pixel graphics are good, but not amazing. The music is also pretty nice, but there aren't many tracks. After a few runs, it gets very repetitive, to the point where I, a person who usually sticks through with a games music until the end, had to use my music library instead.Unfortunately, all of these facts point toward the game being an obvious mobile port, designed to be played in short bursts of playtime. As a result, the interface is a bit huge when playing in full screen, and the options menu is very lackluster (not that it needs to not be, given the simple graphics of the game).The RPG-ish equipment upgrading mechanics aren't bad (I love it when the name of your armor changes based on the aspects you choose to upgrade, possibly giving names such as "immovable cloth ring mail" or "soft diamond shirt"), but what's the point of having a visual representation of your character if he looks like a pixelated Indiana Jones regardless of whether he has mythril plate-mail or a cloth shirt? It's not like there's thousands of equipment possibilities.Overall, 10,000,000 feels very repetitive. It's good at what it does, and presents a spin on the "match 3" puzzler mechanics, but this doesn't remove the repetitiveness problem completely. The equipment upgrades seem like an after-thought because of how they do not affect the character visually. This game hangs in the balance between "I recommend it" and "I don't recommend it", but equipment non-visualization forces me to say that I don't recommend 10,000,000.This does not mean it is a bad game at all, but I just wouldn't recommend it to anyone but the most hardcore "match 3" fans. The developers still update the game though, so I promise to change the recommendation if they do visualize the equipment upgrades. In my opinion, a good "match 3" has to have a good core system and a great spin on the formula. Visualizing the upgrades would make the spin in this one great, instead of "just" good.EDIT 2015/05/28 - Noticed I misspelt the title of the game every single time by forgetting the commas. Whoops...

												A fantastic puzzle game, 10,000,000 thrives on the ability to hop right back in after a crushing defeat. Your ultimate goal is to secure a score of 10,000,000, finally being able to escape from the clutches of a castle that you've been locked away in. If not, check the game out on a sale. 8.7/10

content:
Posted: May 11, 2013
												10,000,000 is one of those great little casual time wasters that you can pick every once in a while to grind for 5 more minutes then put back down again until the next time. The core gameplay mechanic is the basic tile matching we've seen in so many games by now, 10,000,000's own little unique aspect to this rather tired mechanic is that instead of moving individual tiles you move entire columns. This however does not change the concept significantly and if you have played a tile matching game in the past you'll figure this one out in no time at all.The interesting aspect of 10,000,000. And what separates it from so many other similar games, is the way it approaches the timing mechanic. on top of your screen you have a little guy running along in a dungeon, as he progresses he will encounter various obstacles such as doors and monsters each pushing him slowly out of the screen if you do not match the right tiles on the board below. This creates quite a bit more purpose than your usual tile matcher where you just match what you can, as quickly as you can. Here you might wanna save those keys in case you run into a chest, or be careful not to spend too many swords and staffs if you think you're getting close to a tough monster.The game also feature a small metagame, as you match tiles and progress through the dungeon you earn wood, stone, gold and experience which can be used to open up shops and improve your various abilities.All in all 10,000,000 is a fun little game, nothing spectacular, nothing really exciting but a solid time waster. Unfortunately while the time waster genre as such is perfect for mobile games it does not fit quite as well on the PC and although this one of the best examples I've seen in a long time it still doesn't quite measure up to the standards that you would expect from a game that costs money.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2013
												I thoroughly enjoyed this fine little time waster.So, yes. It's kind of like Bejeweled. The matches you make down below push your character through combat and exploration above. Each "run" through the dungeon takes a minute or two. But as you run, you achieve a series of objectives which the game gradually presents to you, which leads to improved skills.The game's genius is the way it rewards you not for a lifetime score, but instead for pushing your single-run high score higher and higher, until you can reach 10,000,000 in a single run. As your character improves a bit with each run, cresting your previous high score becomes theoretically easier each time you run the dungeon. Die, and you can either quit the game, or try one more run almost instantly.It's not a deep game, but I can't think of many games that made "just one more turn" so compelling. Like, "Civilization"-style compelling. It's so easy to try again, over and over. A minute here, a minute there, next thing you know, 2 hours have gone by.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												This is a highly addictive game. A very fast paced match-three puzzle/action/rpg.  Match three swords/staves to deal damage to enemies as you run along to your exit, collect gold, wood and experiance to build better equipment and learn new skills. It will have you rage quitting and then moments late, you find yourself oddly compelled to open it up again and continue where you finished off. The graphics style is pretty neat, you don't really play this sort of game for the graphics though, the fast paced music keeps the momentom going as well. There is next to zero replayability however, once you escape, you won't want to carry on playing, as you will have already full upgraded your castle, armour and abilities anyway. Yes you can keep trying to beat your highscore, but that's just not my thing. Most people will probably have this in their library from a bundle or maybe just for farming trading cards, but if you want a pick up and play game will keep you playing for hours on hours, 10,000,000 is really worth a shot.

												Interesting little tile match game with RPG elements. Unlike some games with additional RPG elements this game makes them necissary, your weapon and armor upgrades allow you to get further in the game and without the RPG elements it would be nearly impossible to get to the victory condition of 10,000,000 points in a single run. The graphics are visually uninteresting but that is not that big of an issue as you can allways tell the difference between the different tiles and enemies. It bearly takes up any space on your hard drive so it is definately good for weaker PCs. my only real issue with it is the controlls. The laptop i am using utilizes a nub mouse so i have a bit of trouble quickly moving it around the board. This game almost needs a touchscreen to be able to reach it's fullest potential. On a basic PC 5/10, on a Touchscreen 7/10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												10,000,000 is a primitive gauntlet running match 3 puzzle game. Your mission is to ultimately score 10,000,000 points to free yourself from the dungeon, but you have to purchase a bunch of upgrades using gold and experience points before you will be able to achieve that goal. Upgrades are available for your sword, staff, armor, and shield. Plus you can buy additional training attributes through earned experience points. Then there are the potions which have both positive and negative effects that you must weigh to determine whether to activate them or not.The gameplay consists of frantically matching gems to attack or unlock doors and chests in an effort to keep your character from hitting the left edge of the screen. Your character continues running to the right as long as you match the right gems to vanquish your enemies or open doors and chests. There is no polish on this game whatsoever. The concept is nice, but the game itself is pretty cheesy. However, for a buck, is does provide reasonable entertainment value.

Your goal is to achieve 10,000,000 points in a single run, to earn your freedom.LikedGraphics. 8-bit, nothing extraordinary, but, neither bad.Content. No clear indication on when you're about to lose (HP, time limit, screen end).Overall, a good game for short, casual sessions, nothing too hard, but neither, too easy. content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Terrible name aside, this is a semi-decent time-waster in the classic "match 3" puzzle genre. The twist in this one is that the matching mechanic works in conjunction with the actions your character takes at the top of the screen. The character's goal is to keep moving to the right, clearing obstacles such as monsters, treasure chests and locked doors. In order to clear those obstacles, you need to match specific types of tiles (swords to kill monsters, keys to open chests, etc). Getting hit or not matching tiles causes you to slow down and creep towards the left side of the screen. If you get pushed all the way back, the run is over. After each run, you return to a dungeon where upgrades can be purchased using the resources collected during the run (wood, stone, gold and experience). And that's pretty much all there is to it. Basically, you just keep running through the dungeon and buying upgrades when you die. Reaching certain score milestones causes you to rank up, which allows you to achieve higher scores and travel further into the dungeon. The ultimate goal is to score the titular 10,000,000 points and escape. On the technical front, the graphics are extremely simple, done in a low-res pixel style. It works for what it is, but the visuals are really nothing to write home about. I did really like the music, though. It's pretty catchy and very NES-esque. In summary, if you are a fan of "match 3" games and don't mind spending a few hours on the mindless grind it takes to complete (I would estimate around 5-6 hours or so), then by all means, give this a shot. However, I really must reiterate that the gameplay is the very definition of a grind - the whole experience from start to finish is extremely repetitive. If you have a short attention span or really don't like doing the same thing over and over for hours, do NOT buy this game. Additionally, I have to say I also think the price is a little too high. For some reason, it's double what it costs on iOS, which doesn't make a whole lot of sense. I'm not saying it's a rip-off, but this might be one of those cases where you may want to wait and see if it goes on sale at some point.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												10,000,000. An RPGish, Bejeweled-like game. Well... ok...While the game does have an interesting concept it annoyingly relies on luck and what tiles the game decides to generate more than anything else, much like Bejeweled or similar puzzle games. If a monster is in your path, you'll have to quickly match sword or staff tiles to do damage. A locked chest requires matching key tiles. And as tiles are random, one might find oneself stuck, matching any tiles at all, hoping to match enough of what is needed before time is up.At the start of the game, be prepared to lose, quite often, until enough materials are gathered to unlock upgrades. While initially the upgrades that can be purchased come in handy and allow one to make quick work of monsters, the upgrades have a max level which in my opinion is too low. Especially during the latter ranks, and especially when fighting bosses. Even completely maxed out requires, more often than not, way too many tile matches and wastes way too much time. However, there are items to find thru out the dungeon run which can help somewhat. Scrolls that will change wood or stone tiles to keys, swords, or staves. Various weapons and orbs to hurl at monsters. Skeleton keys to easily unlock chests or locks. And food items that will give you a time boost. With that said, the weapons, orbs and skeleton keys must be used rather precisely; if used a split second too early when arriving upon a chest or monster the item does nothing and disappears. The same can be said for tiles too. It would have been nice if there was some leeway as making sure the dungeon runner is close enough to an obstacle before using items can waste valuable time, even if just a split second.And possibly the biggest time waster in the game, combos. Match some tiles, more fall down and they match. Combo! They are sometimes handy like during a boss fight. Except when the tiles continue to fall and continue to match it becomes a potential death trap. Yes, I've lost more than once awaiting tiles to stop falling and matching others because during this time nothing else can be done. And if the reason I lost wasn't because I ran out of time, it was shortly after because the combo completely used up tiles that would have came in handy just a few seconds later.Replay value? Prepare to spend several hours upgrading everything before even attempting a run for 10,000,000. But after one does achieve freedom by getting to a score of 10,000,000, the only reason I can think of to come back to this game would be to try for a higher personal score (no Steam leaderboards), or to earn all achievements. Personally, once I complete all the achievements I doubt I will ever play this again.Is 10,000,000 fun? Sure, it can be. Would I recommend it? Hmm. Not at the full price of $4.99. I picked it up on sale for less than a dollar. At that price it was worth it. While I don't really want to vote thumbs down, I'm going to have to since Steam has no neutral option.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
A nice fusion of match 3 and runner gamesThanks to the popularity of Bejeweled, and the over abundance of the easy to make endless runner game, both genres on their own are fairly stale at this point. Some developers will try to mix them up, usually by adding RPG elements or otherwise an artificial sense of progression. 10,000,000 is one of the first I've seen to combine both genres together. The result is quite refreshing. Running for high score in and of itself is not the goal. Along the way you fight monsters, at which point you're stopped and brought to a match 3 game for battle. Said match 3 game is what you've come to expect in the kind with RPG elements; attack, magic, defend, money, and so on. What separates this from usual runners and match 3 is the sense of progression. Every battle gives you gold and XP, which you can use to upgrade your various battle pieces and stats. You're encouraged to keep at it, as the more you play and the farther you get, you can build and get that much farther the next time. Though the game can get a bit grindy towards the end, where you need a lot of XP to get the final upgrades, on the whole it's solidly paced and rarely feels cheap. And like runners and match 3s, it's designed to be done in short bursts, so you can stop when it gets annoying and come back later without missing a beat. All towards an actual goal beyond "getting a high score"If you're a fan of endless runners or match 3s, and enjoy games with 8 bit aesthetics and sounds, give this one a shot. It's great fun if you know what to expect.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Match 3 style games are mostly about 'randomness' and 'luck' with only a pinch of 'skill'. As such these games will take you on an emotional roller coaster; when things don't go your way you will feel deep low's of frustration. But when things are going your way you feel elation from the accomplishment of beating the odds. This game can be very hard, you need to be extremely quick in matching tiles. There is a sort of 'continual countdown timer' where if you do not match tiles quickly enough then your 'session' will come to an end. You can increase your session 'time' by creating a match 4 or 5 of certain tiles or by eating food. On the other hand, if enemies hit you then your 'time' will decrease. The style of 'matching tiles' in this game is similar to 'Puzzle Kingdoms' except in this game you can slide as far as you like along the entire row or column. You will fail alot in this game especially at the harder difficulties as the odds are stacked against you. But 'winning' every play session is not how this game works. You just take each 'play session' as far as you can; you will earn resources and experience every play session which you keep regardless. You spend this upgrading your dwellings, weapon, armor, spells, equipment, etc. So the idea is that you are playing the game for the match 3 puzzle/challenge and just let the progression happen in the background naturally.I feel this game is more for an advanced or veteran match 3 puzzle player and will not be friendly to new comers of the genre.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1
												As a puzzle and strategy enthusiast, I've played my fair share of games and it's always a treat when a game brings something new to the table.  Deviating from the typical 'Match 3' formula, you may find snapshots of the game misleading--the tiled board looks just like any other matching game--but 10000000 has a surprise for you:  You're not going to move the tiles.  You're going to move the BOARD.'Hah!', I hear you scoff.  'That doesn't seem like much of a difference.'  That's what I thought, too, until I played it.  Manipulating the board this way bends your brain in a completely different direction, as you cannot simply adjust one tile at a time.  Every move you make will affect the entire playing field in ways you may not be able to predict at first and it adds new complexity as you struggle to speed through each encounter, which brings me to the other half of the gameplay:You will encounter various monsters with different resistances and weaknesses, locks to pick, chests to open, and all the while the clock is working against you to clear the precise tiles you need to beat each challenge in a matter of seconds.  It comes with an RPG element that rewards your accomplishments and encourages you even after a defeat and, on the whole, it makes for a very engaging experience.  As for flaws, the music can become a bit droning after awhile and it's likely to become stuck in your head very quickly, and a few cracks show in the few scattered misspellings (you're going to be 'poisioned' quite a bit), but on the whole, it's a good game.I feel like the developers missed an opportunity by not including more for the player to do.  Sure, you can keep playing it as long as you like, trying to raise your high score, but since the game revolves around meeting certain score or endurance goals, once you have completed all of said goals and related achievements, it feels like there's no further challenge.  It's just about right for the price and should provide several hours of entertainment.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												It's a Match-3 game, with a simple objective: Get 10,000,000 points. The narrative throws in something about escaping a dungeon, but really that's a lame excuse for the mechanics.Fortunately, the mechanics are where the game shines. The gameplay reminds me of a more strategic version of Chuzzle, which is pretty high praise. You automatically gain points as your avatar keeps moving through the dungeon, but that doesn't continue for long before an obstacle stops your progress and starts whittling away the time you have remaining on your run.Your matches are used to overcome obstacles and collect resources in order to boost your score. The resources that you collect can be expended at your home base (like, say, a less complicated version of Rogue Legacy) to provide upgrades and bonuses to plow through obstacles more easily, defend yourself against said obstacles, or on the rare occasion just provide a percentage boost to your overall score.The graphics are deliberately retro, even excessively so, but it definitely has a unified aesthetic. The music and sounds are sufficient, but I found after about 30 minutes of playing and hearing all the tracks, I enjoyed it more with the music off and a different soundtrack in the background.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												OVER 10,000,000!  Yes, that is the goal of this game.  Even though the concept of match-3 puzzle have been use hundreds of time, the addition of RPG and action element make this game stand above all.  The gameplay is very simple because is a match-3 puzzle, but unlike other, you have to focus more on your charactor and the next objective that you have to clear, if a monster stand before you, you need to match attack tiles, if a door or chest you need to match keys.  There is also material tiles, after every run end, you gain the materials and experience points to help strengthen your charactor, which help you on the next run.Unlike the mobile counterpart, the PC port does not feel like endless at all.  Once you upgrade everything to the max, which is fairly easy grind, and reach 10,000,000, the game feel finish because of lack of a leaderboard.  I must note that the achievement does add extra challenge but once you get use to the control, you shouldn't have problem clearing them.Overall, I must say this game is a good buy for the listing price, can even be a must buy when it on sale.  You may want to play this game on your phone though, is it a phone game afterall.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
An Awesome Bejeweled-Like Game [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]Wow... just wow! Too bad it only has a limited playtime (5 hours). It is a sort of tech-demo: the gameplay is solid, but the game is not so refined (for example, upon completing a quest you are forced to exit the dungeon for refreshing the others) and lacks some customization (no resolution settings), quality (bitmaps everywhere!) and variety (maybe different classes, hero's stats, different levels, and so on).What's about the gameplay? You advance the dungeon by combining items of the same type in your lower part of the screen: wands for magical attack, swords for physical attack, chests for loot and so on... enemies can attack you and slow you down (or kill!).Advice: you can upgrade your buildings by clicking "upgrade" in the upper portion of the windows... It took me 3 hours to notice it.I am looking forward to 20,000,000! With a little more dedication it could be the next Puzzle Quest (at the moment, the pinnacle of the genre)!Best played with Keyboard and MouseRecommended Buy Price < 2$Score 8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Frustrating RPG Puzzle Freedom Simulator, which while wrecks your very soul into a slobbering pathetic of lifeless drool (and will leave you contemplating your very being) offers one of the most (strangely) rewarding completions ever. It's a simple game that on the surface should be completed within a matter of minutes - the goal is simple: Achieve 10,000,000 points in 1 one and you're free to leave. If you die your score is reset. Yet, it's not that simple. Not only do you face a string of increasingly difficult monsters on your run to freedom, you also have to overcome your own inability to match 3 or more tiles together. So simple.Yet so freaking difficult.And thus addicition is born. The feeling you can beat this game, with the secretly scoffing bellows of laughter from whatever twisted mind designed this game spur you on to play it. There's not much more to say than that. It would probably be best enjoyed as an iOS/Android game, certainly one where you could pick and play in small time windows, rather than long drawn out PC sessions (and a quick look shows that it is available for less than £2 most of the time). If you like puzzle games, and games that tease you with their simplicity (yet burn you with their difficulty) than this game is for you. If, however, you cannot stand iOS/Android apps, and despise their existance on Steam... avoid it.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Short version: 7/10; only buy it at around $0.99 or a bundle, imo.I didn't expect much from 10,000,000 coming in, but I was pleasantly surprised; I saw $0.99, and saw a game described as a puzzle / RPG, so I was sold. At the heart of the game is a "connect 3" game (I think that's the term...?); you have a board of tiles, and must match three or more to do something. While you're playing the game, you'll be faced with either enemies, a locked door, or a locked chest, and must match the correct corresponding tiles to advance. To combat the enemies, you must connect either the melee tiles (which can crit), or the magic tiles (which can have special effects, ranging from freezing them solid, to poisoning them). To combat the doors and/or chests, you must match the keys. Once you open the chest, you either get gold (one of three currencies used in the game to unlock / upgrade things), or a one-time use item that helps you in fighting. Other tiles that are used are: wood (currency), stone (currency), item (gives you an item to use in combat), and wildcard, which acts as anything, tile-wise. There are a couple of things I don't like about the game, namely the fact that there are situations where it's virtually impossible to win. If the board gives you a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hand, you can't do anything about it (well, you can use an item to randomly change like, five of 25 tiles once...), and will lose. If you don't have any keys on the board, and you run into a chest, well, good luck. While I appreciate that the game has "stronger" and "weaker" monsters, they're not tuned very well; the dragons will make short work of you, unless you have items saved up for them specifically. The graphics might be a turn-off to some players. There's only one song, that's endlessly looped (didn't bother me, but I wanted to mention it). Another annoyance is that if you use your items early, before the enemy is properly aligned with you, you've wasted the item, and it does nothing. Really...? Finally, the hit-detection can be weird, since you *only* use the mouse for this game...most times it was okay, but I did notice it from time to time.With all that said, I enjoy this type of game, and with light RPG elements, and the fact that certain tiles really only work with certain situations, I enjoyed the strategy... when I wasn't raging. As mentioned at the top, I would rate this a 7/10, but would only recommend it at around $1.00 or so (or if it's in a bundle).[I've played the game offline; I've got about four hours played start to finish.]

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												Bejewel meets, Indiana Jones meets, RPG in this odd mix. Fight your way through hordes of monsters, while using your puzzle skill to kill them off. Who knew one day that puzzles would be the bane of dragons.Game play: 7The game play is solid. You start off in a stone room with broken down doors everywhere, that leads into other rooms. With these rooms, you are able to increase your static, from better armor, to better spells, to better score multipliers, to more damage. To be able to unlock each door you must run the ongoing dungeon to earn experience to gain levels and to gain gold. While running the dungeon you are given a Bejewel style puzzle game. On the top of the screen you have the character running, He’ll run into monsters, doors, and chest. That you need to match up the squares to progress further into the dungeon. You are given a time limit. You will slowly be pushed backwards to the left edge of the screen. The faster you kill monsters or unlock things the closer you get to the right side of the screen. Once you pass a certain threshold on the screen you will gain a bonus to your score as long as you keep moving ahead. Each Square has an icon that you need to match up to be able to kill monsters or unlock chest or doors. Each icon has special ability to help you progress deeper. The icons you see are, Wood, Boulder, Wand, Sword, backpack, key and shield. Wood and boulder give you materials to use to build the rooms you see at the start. Wand and sword are attacks depending on the monster they can be either be weaker or stronger vs the type you are using. The backpack can give you items to use in your inventory on the right side of the screen. The key is used to open chest and doors, the shield gives you better armor to take hits better.On the side, you have you’re inventory where you get power ups, From faster moment, to magic attacks, to keys and weapons. They can be very useful. After you die you are able to use the gold and materials you gained from the previous run to build the rooms, or you may hold on to them until next time. The overall object of the game is to get your score to 10,000,000 (Ten million). To be able to escape.Story: 2There isn’t really a story going on here. You are a guy who looks like Indiana Jones who has become trapped in this dungeon that is now trying to escape. Having to fight zombies, demons, dragons and such. That’s pretty much it. This game doesn’t really need much of a story to really enjoy it.Graphics: 6This game takes on the retro 8-bit style. Like many other indie games that uses 8-bit. They are pretty simple as it is. The mix of colors being used range from grays, to lighter colors like reds and blues. It’s a simple pallet of colors over all. The graphics don’t pop out as anything to flashy to it. they are Kinda of flat graphics. In its own right the graphics are decent.Music: 5Like the graphics it takes on an 8-bit sound track. The music is decent sounding but not amazing but yet not horrible either. It does keep in decent pace with the game play. Other than that there isn’t really much else to the music.Final Though:Overall I enjoyed this game a lot. It was fun, and challenging. I found the game play being the best part of this game. However this game kinda of lacks any real re playability. It’s a game that is great for a one time play and not touch it for a while. This game doesn’t stand out to other puzzle games. However the unique thing about this game is the RPG element which gives it a nice touch. Having the Bejewel style puzzle being what you use to fight monsters and unlock stuff with does give this game the bit of edge it needs to push it higher than your average puzzle game. With the mix of gaining gold and materials and being able leveling up to unlock more powers to make you stronger does make this game fun.If you are a puzzle person or someone who simply loves Bejewel like myself you may want to try this game out. If anything this game is cheap so for a few bucks you can’t go wrong with this game.Final Score: 6Check out my Tumblr for more! www.rogue32807.tumblr.com

As always.Score out of 10:-Graphics: 5.6, they say "good old classic", and say someone was too lazy. -Game engine: 9.0, what can go wrong with such a small game? Wait, oh shi~-Game mechanics: 5.2, everything is smooth and fait. Run, farm, match, run, farm, buy, upgrade. Not enough depth in this. I prefer thousands of equipment combinations, which are not linear, and have its merits and flaws. More than 3 levels of upgrades of building and so on. But... it's just a small indie coffee-break game, right?-Game addiction: 2.42, do not know is it nice feature or not, but I usually play 3-4 runs and then quit the game to continue with study or work. Not a Civ or HoMM with "last turn" syndrome.-Gameplay: 10.0, perfect match-3-4-5 game. I even enjoyed this casual staff.TOTAL: 7.01.Slightly better than 7, I mean. For that price game is really nice, and I recommend it to everybody. I hope sequel (99 999 999), will be more RPG-oriented and the world (and your castle) will be much wider.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Match 3 as Action RPG...What sounds like a weird idea actually plays quite nice. You have to reach 10,000,000 Points in score to escape the dungeon.To reach this you have to skill up and gain enough resources to upgrade your character and beat up attacking monsters, instead of hitpoints you have a timeout, which is reached when your character touches the left border of the area. Pros: - Very easy to learn game, the match 3 genre does not need to be explained.- Fast and intuitive gameplay.- Solid programmed, No crash encountered during gameplay.Cons: - Soundtrack can get fast enervating... either switch it off or keep it on low volumeRecomended:If you don't have a match 3 game in your library you might wish to try this one. It's about five bucks for this game, which might look like a bit high. But if you have a chance to get this game during a sell out or otherwise cheap. Take your chance. I am not saying it's too expensive, since the programmers have made it a good experience to play. Addiction Incoming!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
Introduction10,000,000 is an hybrid RPG/Action/Puzzle game. Steady progress in the game allows you to gain the tools to break out of your prison.Title: 10,000,000Genre: Action, Casual, Indie, RPGDeveloper: EightyEightGames Publisher: EightyEightGames Release Date: 15 Jan, 2013Main ReviewIt's not an easy game, but it's addictive in how it works. Your character progresses in a dungeon and you match blocks together in order to keep on moving, matching keys to open a door or chest, swords or shields to fight. The game is a race against time. It's quite fast paced and easy to get into, though hard to keep going and finish it. The RNG can sometimes really screw you up - and you may need to reset a level just because you didn't get what you needed for a long time. It's satisfying to see the big numbers appear, and each shake of the screen when you match blocks is pretty cool.You need to reach the score 10,000,000 in order to complete the game, and all the runs beforehand allow you to buy upgrades such as potions, weapons, gear, score accumulators in order to improve your score further, get better upgrades - until you're good enough to hit the top score to beat the game. You can collect four items that stay with you even when a run fails, to make future runs easier. It can get really fraustrating, since even if you have every single upgrade, getting the final score is still difficult. However that also makes it fun! The music also helps a lot to get you more stressed.Visually the game at times make it hard to see what's going on, especially when managing your position in the game. The character screen is small. On the left of the main "running" screen is a skull, on the right is a finish line and a smily face. If your character is at the right of the screen, it's harder to counter a threat since you don't see it until it's already on you. If your character is on the left of the screen, you'll die a lot faster if you don't get the block combination you need to open a door, since your run ends if the skull catches up with you.Pros and ConsPro'sAddictiveChallenging/Fast pacedGood musicFun system to work withConsAddictiveChallenging/Fast PacedMUSIC MAKES YOU STRESSEDRNG hates youThe screen doesn't moveTL'DROverall VerdictI recommend this game to other people. I think it's worth a playthrough, and at this price, it's nothing to complain about. Be prepared to get very addicted ... and possibly shout a bit at the screen.Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

Posted: February 3, 2014
												I've seen a lot of hating on the game for it being a grind-fest, repetitive, having barriers that force loss and such...yes, the game makes you play repeated sessions of increasingly difficult 'dungeons' for challenges that unlock gold and materials and experience to make your matches do more and to upgrade your character and such. That's the gameplay beyond the tile-matching based upon what you need to get you through the obstacle you're currently encountering at the top of the screen whether it be a monster, chest, or door. I feel like too much is expected of this title for absolutely no reason. It's a game worth the about $0.99 you'll likely pay for it and can be a quick way to pass a bit of time while your buddy walks the dog and takes out the garbage before you get back to DotA 2, TF2, etc. It's got a somewhat satisfyingly simple play that, while sometimes awkward with the mouse, doesn't frustrate simply because you aren't playing because you're 'so into it,' you're playing because you need a time sink that you can put down and pick up. For what the game's worth I'd give it a 6/10.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												What is 10,000,000?  It sounds like the beginning to a terrible essay but I've had friends constantly ask me while I play.  Enjoy Bejeweled but are terribly bored of rolling in riches and crushed gem shards?  Puzzle Quest quests just not instantly gratifying enough?  Well welcome to 10,000,000!You are an explorer trapped in a dungeon and you must fight your way through hordes of monsters and dragons.  STORY.  Not really, that's pretty much all you get.  You match tiles to use magic or melee attacks.  Match keys to open chests and doors.  Oh, but that's not all.  You need to match lumber and stone to gather resources for your home base.  Home base, well that's where you get all beefed up for your next expedition.  But what happens when you finally reach 10,000,000 points?Farther you get in the dungeon, the more points you get along with experience and other such wonders to help you in future journeys.It's a nice time killer when you are waiting for friends for other such online gaming shenanigans or just when you really don't want to think and maintain some level of sanity.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												10,000,000 is a tile-matching game with a sliding mechanic unlike bejeweled. It features RPG elements, item managements and potion selections at the start of your game. This game is as good for casual players as it is for gamers, because of the scaling difficulty and the possibility to farm for upgrades in the earlier difficulties.While the game has it's fair share of "Get lucky to finish certain missions" I found the game to be really enjoyable! The soundtracks are simply amazing, after playing for 2 hours I had at least 2 soundtracks stuck in my head. The graphics are ok low budget graphics, but again the game is only $4.99 USD.I've completed this game in around 5-6 hours with an additional 2 hours to complete the hardest achievements. As for the replay value, it's probably gonna be fun for an additional 5+ hours after you finish the game.Overall, I strongly recommend to buy this game if you like tile-matching games!

Posted: August 22, 2015
												One of the best match-3 (Bejeweled) puzzle games out there. As you match tiles your character on top runs through the dungeon fighting monsters, opening chests and doors, and slaying bosses. To melee you match the sword blocks, to use magic you match the staves. Simple in concept, but quite challenging.As you continue to harder floors, you gain gold that you can use to upgrade your character making him stronger, and giving yourself various abilities to gain an edge.I also failed to mention you are on a time limit, each time your character is hit you get moved furthor off the screen, so it's best to stay agile and move as quickly as possible between obstacles. It's extremely addicting and definitely worth a playthrough, I only wish there was a sequel..

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												10,000,000 is a very fun game where your objective is to get a score of 10,000,000. The game is basically a fusion of a bejeweled and item based rpg game, but slightly different mechanics than bejeweled as it moves the whole column instead of swapping the two.This game is not easy by any means as it is more complex than it seems. The matching matters because there are melee and magic attacks based on your matches. There are also matches that give you wood and stone which you can use to upgrade your "home" outside. By upgrading your "home" you can get upgrades that help you in your next run. You also get experience points which you can buy certain upgrades for different things with. Lastly you get gold which you can upgrade your armor, weapons, and shield with. There are a lot of things to upgrade, but the game gets harder and harder. Basically if the left side of the screen catches up with you, you are forced to leave the run with whatever score you obtained. I really enjoyed the concept and especially the execution a lot. Furthermore, the music fit really well with the graphics and vice versa. This was just a rather complete game.The only thing I would say isn't as good with this is the purple treasure matching thingies or whatever they are. They really didn't do too much help. Also the tutorial was rather short and I had to learn some things again the hard way later on.But those are just minor compared to the positives. I would recommend this game to anybody who likes a roguelike genre, BeJeweled related matching (but different), or anyone who just wants to have some challenging fun.Rating: 8.2/10Recommend Price: $2 or under

												10,000,000 is a simple straightforward match3 /rpg  action game with one goal in mind: score 10,000,000 points in one run to escape the dungeon. It may seem impossible initially within the first ten minutes of the game, however as the game progresses and as your rank increases, you'll find yourself having your goal become tantalizingly closer and closer. Of course, it is a bit of a grind fest; you'll need to earn points and materials for upgrades  and to pass certain ranks.   I would say this though, if you hate match 3 games or if you aren't that good at them, this game is not for you.  Nevertheless, it's a great little addicting game that isn't pretentious  and provides lots of hours of fun.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												10,000,000!  The name you should never call your game because it makes it difficult to find in search engines.The game combines classic match-3 gameplay with an RPG in a way that you wouldn't think would work well, but it does.  The game is quite simple: Venture into the dungeon and match the applicable tiles on the board to fight monsters, charge up your shield, collect resources, and unlock doors and chests.  The run ends when you run out of time (HP and time are the same) and you use the resources gained to upgrade your equipment and train new bonuses.  The ultimate goal is to make a dungeon run ending in a score of 10,000,000 points.The gameplay is quite fast paced so you will need a quick eye and hand to succeed.  There is some strategy involved with your upgrade path as well as enemy damage resistance but also the inherent factor of luck in relying on a board of random tiles.  Sometimes you will fail because you just can't get the tiles you need.  Fortunately it doesn't really matter much in the long run because you still gain resources to use for upgrades to improve your next run.It's a nice little game, give it a try!

												It's a skinner box. Just keep playing to get more gold to buy more upgrades to have a better chance at matching three to keep going deeper into the dungeons to get to the arbitrary goal of 10,000,000 points. I can see how a normal person playing this in short bursts of 5 minutes over the course of a month or more while on some public transit might think this is fine. Please, just go buy literally any other indie game that interests you. There's a good chance it's probably better than this.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Note: I like this game much better on Android. The touchscreen interface makes it significantly more responsive. I think Windows 8 with touchscreen would also be fine. It just plays smoother.This game is basically Bejeweled with RPG elements. I love Bejeweled with over 60 hours clocked in on Bejeweled 3. If you're familiar with those types of block matching games, it's pretty easy to pick this up and play.The game can be frustrating. You need to make appropriate matches to meet the needs of your character who is running a dungeon at the top of the screen. If there's a locked door or chest, you need to match keys. If it's a monster, you need to match swords or staves. When you're not doing that, you want to match wood and stone to upgrade various shops. Sometimes you just don't get the types of blocks you need and the game delivers a brutal beating if you stop to consider your options. You have to keep matching non-stop to advance. If you hesitate, it's over. Some of the dungeon objectives are survival-based like "stay alive for 90 seconds." It's not as easy as that sounds. As you upgrade your armor, weapons, and abilities, however, the game's difficulty decreases. One ability, for example, reduces the number of keys to open locks to just one key.10000000 is a fun game. It took me about 2.5 hours to level up all my items and rooms and beat the game. It's still fun to replay.

have all your stuff its problems shine,once your on your final task of getting the 10 million your start to see how the game works againt the player as EVERYTHING IS RANDOM,in a game like isaac or nuclear throne there are random elements but your skill makes up for that and technically every run can be won if your good enough, with 10 million this is not the case as everything that is going on is random,such as your might  need a sword to kill a monster, but all your getting are keys,chests,rocks,wood and you have no scrolls to turn tiles into swords, you can match and match till the cows come home but by the time you get a sword your have wasted to much time and your to far to the left side of the screen to make it back and you die.or in each level there is a boss monster like a dragon, they are hard to kill and take a lot of time off you from them dealing dammage and how long it takes to kill one, sometimes they can randomized close together so you can get done fighting one dragon and barly suviving and then 3 monsters later there is another dragon and you have spent everything on the 1st so you die.however seen your score get so close to 10 million but not quite reaching it, douse give this addicting feel of just one more run, just one more run till you beat it.my final verdict for the game is a average 3/5its simple and sweet,the visuals, game play and music are funand the game starts of greatits just let down at the end as you can no longer increece you stats to beat the monsters is pure luck, hopping that the right tiles will show up on your run, hopping that the monsters have randomized right so you get lost of weak ones to give a a fighting chance.if you are a fan of match 3 games and you can deal with all elemets not in the players control(what tiles you get, what order the monsters are going to be in, what items you get from chests)then give it a try, but if your are a player that likes skill or requires some level of control then i cant recommend this game and would tell you to pass on it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This is a match 3 (or more) kind of game.With the whole point to get 10 000 000 score to finish it.Easier said than done.You match swords & staves to attack.Shields to prevents damage. Keys to unlock gates and chests, etc etc.Which is what you'll be doing all the time for the rest of the game.You also can get items and scrolls while playing (and they carry over if not used to the next round).To use on enemies, chests, lose less time (and yes, the game is time based so if you're too slow you lose.)In your home base you can unlock rooms.Each room has different upgrades.Some for skills which you use xp for.Others have potions aka modifers.Then you have all weapons, armor, shields to upgrade.Pretty straight forwards. It's a gold sink, a time sink..It keeps you grinding. And grinding is all it's about.The music is great, just one song though I think. Very catchy however.Graphics are pixels. I like pixels. Maybe you don't? But, if you do, this is a really nice game to look at in my opinion.Lots of different enemies that LOOK different and aren't just reskins.That's pretty much it. I enjoyed it alot.Amount of time to beat the game: 10 hours.>>>WORTH IT<<<

Posted: September 25, 2015
												tl;dr - It's pretty fun and worth a play through.I'm not a huge fan of match 3 games, but I generally enjoy them every now and then. If you're not a fan, I doubt this game will change your mind. Your success in this game often comes down to luck, but each run is quick enough that it can keep your attention and make you want to try again, especially if you've just unlocked something good. The pixel graphics are a bit annoying, but not enough to make you want to stop playing. This is one of those games that can look like garbage, but still be satisfying to play.Overall, 7/10 for me. Good enough to finish, but I doubt I'd ever come back to it.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I wanted to like this, but in the end found it to be rather boring.Conceptually, what led me to want to get this game:Match-3 with a slightly different mechanism for moving the pieces on the board.RPG elements.What I didn't like:It's basically an endless runner in Match-3 form. You play until you die, in a way like Tetris. Some people will like this. I was expecting Puzzle Quest-like matches against opponents.That manner of moving the pieces on the board was different, which is commendable in terms of differentiation, but I found I didn't like it. For whatever reason, it just doesn't click in my head, so any combos I get are by chance.Playing this game with a mouse. It would definitely be better on a touch screen.Unfortunately I haven't finished this. I'm not enjoying it enough to continue. To beat the game, you need to get 10,000,000 points. I've maxed out my character but am topping out at about 7,300,000. And as stated before, I'm not "getting" the game, so there's no improvement. For me, 10,000,000 points is a dream, so I might as delete the game now.4/10

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												If Puzzle Quest is like Bejeweled on Classic mode, 10000000 is like Bejeweled on Lightning mode, with Progress Quest hooked up to it. Each dive into the dungeon is a frenzy of matching three to buy you more time to match more three. Then at the end of the run you take the gold, exp, stone, and wood you get and make numbers go up so you can do more matching against enemies who themselves have slightly bigger numbers.It's probably the emptiest gaming experience I've yet bought on Steam.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												This would get a thumbs up if we were talking about the Android version of the game.  Unfortunately, the control scheme on the Windows version ruins the game.  This is a game meant for quick swipes of the fingertip, which doesn't translate well when done via mouse.  Also, the game style is meant for quick 5 or 10 minute sessions, more likely when you are away from your gaming rig on a mobile device.  It's not worth the 5 dollar entry price, but worth a buck during a sale.  Still, if you buy this game, get it on Android.  I will admit, the "Your keyboard will not avail you, flame of adur!"  did get a chuckle out of me.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Just not good...I used to be sort of addicted to match-3 games, and I have played a couple of combat variants, like this one, but 10M, is addictive without being good.Let's pretend for a moment that the graphic is cool pixel art stuff, and it just doesn't plain sucks, or that the music is chimpunk tune, and not just a single boring short melody: the gameplay is just a repetitive mess, and there are a number of design flaws that make it really annoying.Point is: graphic and sound doesn't matter, if you have some really really cool idea (nope: nothing new here...) or if the gameplay is fun (nope), but what should save a boring, bad looking, bad sounding repetitive game? Simphaty for indie development? :/Let's take the upgrade system, for instance: while matching and killing enemies, you get experience, wood, stone and gold. The problem is, that the experience pratically ceases to be useful very early in the game, while wood and stone become essentially useless after you have upgraded all your stores (quite early on). So you keep getting it, you watch them increase, but you cannot do anything with it. How frustrating is that?!Sure, you can grind to upgrade your stuff and, eventually, you get better, but the problem is that the game never feels very satisfying. It's just not fun.So instead of reaching 10000000 points, I think I will concentrate on the 10000000 things I will get to do *instead* of playing this game.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												10,000,000 has the spirit of a roguelike... randomized encounters that will certainly defeat you after some time; leaving you to start again.  This works best when there are a wealth of mechanics and things to explore, but that is sadly lacking here.  Two basic types of obstacles (enemies and locks) are re-skinned with minor tweaks to gameplay for the entire game, which all takes place in the same grey hallway.  Match three mechanics have been done better elsewhere.  Skip this one.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is good and for the asking price of a buck its a great deal as you get a lot of gameplay for a low price. I did enjoy the graphics. They are not super nice looking but they set the mode and are colorful. The sound is retro as well and is nice. The game is a little bit Bejewled and little like Puzzle quest with a super short timer. The gameplay is a match 3 type game so its easy to pick up and play. Thats also probably its greatest failing is its got one trick and it plays it over and over again. Now like I said the gameplay is fun but thats all you do in this game is go the dungeon that generally lasts around 2 minutes or less and then once you have finished inside the dungeon then get better gear and head towards the dungeon. Thats it. I do have advice for what I love to see in a sequel if there is one. Skill levels for the clock as its super fast and games are super short. Make the dungeon a little bit more different the further down you go besides the different bad guys. Add torches or rocks or make it a different background color so you realize your in a different dungeon. I would like this expanded to include more unique gameplay other then going in and coming out. 7/10 for the price and the gameplayWhen the sale goes off I would rate it about a 6/10 this game is gonna drive some people nuts and some will love it. I am in the middle. I just finished this game played a total of 7hours not bad

In fact, you will probably just hit 'reset' and start from the beginning again, to try to beat it faster the second time through. Recommended for any RPG/Puzzle fusion fans. Quick reflexes a prerequisite.

												This game is good and for the asking price of a buck its a great deal as you get a lot of gameplay for a low price. I did enjoy the graphics. They are not super nice looking but they set the mode and are colorful. The sound is retro as well and is nice. The game is a little bit Bejewled and little like Puzzle quest with a super short timer. The gameplay is a match 3 type game so its easy to pick up and play. Thats also probably its greatest failing is its got one trick and it plays it over and over again. Thats it. I do have advice for what I love to see in a sequel if there is one. Skill levels for the clock as its super fast and games are super short. Make the dungeon a little bit more different the further down you go besides the different bad guys. Add torches or rocks or make it a different background color so you realize your in a different dungeon. I would like this expanded to include more unique gameplay other then going in and coming out. 7/10 for the price and the gameplayWhen the sale goes off I would rate it about a 6/10 this game is gonna drive some people nuts and some will love it. I am in the middle. I just finished this game played a total of 7hours not bad

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												10,000,000 is a solid if unspectacular match-3/RPG variant where you face off against a series of obstacles and enemies, gradually obtaining the cash and resources you need to get upgrades, which in turn allow you to progress further, until eventually you score the titular number of points and win/escape/etc.The game is generally good at what it does, but there isn't all that much to it - my playtime reflects a completed game with all but one achievement, and people who are actually good at match-3 games could probably get through it significantly faster. The game board consists of swords, staves, shields, keys, stone, and wood (and purple blocks that give items) - swords and staves deal damage to monsters, shields protect you from monsters, keys unlock chests and doors, and stone and wood can be used to unlock and upgrade shops. Defeating monsters and opening chests also provide you with gold and experience to upgrade your damage and armor or train abilities. You also have several quests to pursue at any given time (generally either 'do X thing Y times in one run' or 'do some cool thing once') which give bonus resources and unlock new tiers to face.The core gameplay revolves around matching the right pieces to defeat the threat you're currently up against - your location on the dungeon screen essentially represents your health, and while blocked by a monster or locked chest/door, you'll be pushed to the left. If you make the proper matches or find restorative items, you can recover and progress to the right. You also get three (four once you upgrade) inventory slots to hold items, generally to help deal with a specific threat (magic orbs for monsters, skeleton keys for chests). However, since these randomly-obtained items are the only way to interact with the board other than making matches, this can lead to some frustrating moments - if you wind up facing a dragon with a board full of keys, you're probably out of luck even if you waste the keys by clearing them to no use. This is compounded by that four of the seven piece types provide no immediate help against either a chest or a monster, meaning you're often left frantically trying to clear them in the brief moments between encounters.The hub between dungeon runs is fairly minimalistic - you can upgrade weapons and armor, but the upgrades are 'boring' and there are no real choices to be made except for the minor decisions of where to upgrade first. The experience-bought upgrades have a bit more variety, but still boil down to 'make your dungeon runs slightly more effective' - the gameplay doesn't change. Finally, there's an alchemist - you can activate any combination of potions for a given run - most of them enact tradeoffs between certain resources and others but some are more unique.In short, while it's a bit clunky at moments and can be fairly luck-dependent, 10,000,000 features enjoyable gameplay and is a fun diversion.
