content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I wouldn't buy it again.This game can best be described as Tetris-like.  Your object is to arrange the tiles in groups of three or more in order to eliminate the tiles, gain a bonus, and have more tiles drop into the field of play.In my opinion, You Must Build A Boat (YMBAB) -- which is by the same developer -- is exactly like this game and is much better.  If I had bought this game before YMBAB I might have liked it more.  But, unfortunatley, it suffers from the fact that the two games are essentially alike.I have read other reviews that describe this game (and its other incarnation) as adventures in grinding.  This is true.  To be honest, I had enough of grinding when I played WoW for seven years.  I'm tired of grinding.  It's pointless and those moments of my life are more valuable then to keep edging toward some arbitrary goal -- in this case, ten million points.I always have a questionable amount of fun playing games that are laregly influenced by luck.  Perhaps I am not good at thinking visually in three dimensions and, therefore, I'm not able to plan and strategize well in this type of game.Even YMBAB suffers from this influence of luck.  Ultimately, you can move tiles as quickly as you want or need to, but if you don't get the right tiles dropped into place then it you're eventually doomed.  Therefore, it really doesn't matter how well you make decisions, how fast you operate, or what your strategy is.  Eventually, you will succeed just because of the forces and fates of luck.I did enjoy this game -- but to be clear I don't think you need to own both this and YMBAB and YMBAB offers more compelling interest.  There just wasn't enough positive happening here when I succeeded to compel me to continue.Buy either this or YMBAB but not both.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												First real review, because the game really impressed me with how fast the game became mundane.Pro:- Easy control of the board/Responds well to input.- Some chiptune tracks are pretty good (but obviously not made for the game).Cons:- Time restriction on both gameplay segments (restriction on the amount of time you can play on a save is bad, it makes it necessary to complete the game multiple times to get the achievements).- Completely random board (it's not in herently bad, but in the case of a game with specific goals to advance on a time restriction, it goes against fun).- Seemingly random/blind upgrades (you often spend a huge portion of your gold to get 0.1% crit chance, which ultimately makes you feel like the game is working against you, other times, you spend less and you get +10 damage. It makes no sense.).- Little to no variety. (there isn't much else other than what is shown in the tutorial with stats increases).- Very lazy pixel art. (yes, I'm going there).Overall, even though it isn't expensive, I do not recommend as the whole basis of the game is completely random and won't make you feel good for doing good and needs to complete an exponential amount of runs (multiple runs (overall game saves) of multiple runs (individual game runs for ressources)) to do the achievements, which seems to be the only real goal this game has other than it's utterly repetitive "get to 10,000,000 score to escape" that will need you to do the same thing for 10 hours with little to no variety. (upgrades aren't variety in this case, as they add no complexity to the actual runs' gameplay) It's a time waster you have to pay for, and an unsatisfying one at that.

												It's a toss up. Fun in small doses; the mash of match three and endless runner works really well even when executed with some flaws. The game is grindy but gives you plenty to reach for and accomplish. However, the further you get toward the finish, the harder it is to get there - as much as I enjoyed the gameplay along the way, I was honestly relieved when I beat the game because it took several sessions of aggressive play to really hit the scores I needed. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Ultimately nothing more than a grindRather than asking players to simply match icons on a board, the game is centered around a minimalistic dungeon-crawl shown at the top of the screen. Players aim to match sword and wand icons to attack monsters and keys to clear locked chests and doors. The variable value of tiles makes board management incredibly important. Players must constantly clear the shield, pack, wood, and stone icons that are of lesser use during the run in order to seed the board with useful tiles-- especially weapons as monsters can attack the player, costing more precious time. Defeating monsters quickly is both necessary and frustrating as it adds a layer of luck to the game: it is possible to happen upon a long string of monsters without the compartively easier chests and doors, effectively dooming a run since the player doesn't have time to manage the board.Between dungeon runs, the game gives gold, stone, wood, and experience, all of which are used to level-up your strength and defenses. However, none of the upgrades ultimately change the way the game is played, neither increasing the complexity or even effecting the difficulty due to the increasing strength of monsters. Instead, upgrades are a brick wall that serve to force a particular rate of progression upon the player. Players cannot progress into the deeper levels of the dungeon until they grind out enough resources to upgrade their stats. Instead of barring players based upon skill, players are barred based upon time investment.The way the value of tiles changes based upon the scenario presented in the dungeon makes the game decent, but the title ultimately turns out to be more of a grind than anything else due to its simple gameplay and leveling system.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												10,000,000 is one of those rare games that tries to mix RPGs, autorunners, and puzzles.It's one of the many that completely fails to be any good at all 3.First, the RPG elements are clunky. They explain it once, but then give you little to no way to actually improve. You'll always fight monsters the same way with the same spells. And considering the barebones graphics, music, and the looming end, it adds virtually nothing to the gameplay other than an annoying distraction and an indicator of what you now need to match.Secondly, the autorunning nature feels more like an arbitrary way to make it difficult without ever having to change anything on the field or in the game. A vague "end" keeps chasing you. When it reaches you or passes you or some other vague idea of "you reach it" that seems to change from game to game, you lose. Except you can keep matching for a few seconds.And then there's the puzzle elements. They're, at best, clumsy. The game will not simply suggest a certain chain, it all but enforces it. See a skeleton? Get those staff and sword blocks. None of those? Fine, I GUESS get some resources. Oh there's a sword. Ignore that double/chained set, just get that sword or the looming end will get you! But that's not the worst of it. Oh no. The WORST of it, my friends, is that when you scroll it around the screen...it makes no difference if there are 3 blocks. They must be blocks that were initially placed in a way to complete a chain. If you scroll it around and there's 4 swords and you need four swords? Sorry, only the wood resource that had a 3 piece chain will count. Nothing else. This seems like a drastic oversight. Even the likes of Tetris Attack on the SNES would let you change blocks with no outcome, thus allowing a deeper gameplay. This offers no depth in that sense. It has to be already on screen, already apparent, and already set up.All of this combines to create a tedious but inoffensive puzzle experience. But what makes it truly heinous is how many times you repeat a level to complete challenges to get resources to unlock do-Hold on, champ! You flawlessly performed all those tasks, but you need 500 wood and 500 stone for the next door! You only have 300 wood and 120 stones! Nope, get back to the time sink.All in all, I cannot recommend 10,000,000. It is a clunky, rushed, and overall ugly game that seems to hope to garner more love off the Atari-era graphics than any actual quality or effort.

If you're looking for the type 2 RPG, go elsewhere.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												--- 10,000,000 ---* Don't mind my time played here, I have logged 100+ hours of the iOS version because this game is perfect when on the move.* I really don't recommend the Steam version of this game because of the awkward controls.What is this....10,000,000 is a match-3 endless runner with a twist. There is no story to speak of, the goal is to escape the dungeon/castle you find yourself locked into. You do this by getting a high-score of 10,000,000 or above. Sounds easy? It kind of is, the first times. This game get tough as nails when you try and beat it the forth time and beyond tho. This is something the game calls "ace levels" which basically is a NewGame+ mode that ramp up the difficulty progressively. The question is who is even going to want to play this game for that long with these awkward mouse controls? Anyway...The games single biggest problem is it's useless control scheme. I understand that there really are no good alternatives for games like this. (SO DON'T ♥♥♥♥ING RELEASE THEM ON STEAM!) The Steam version of 10,000,000 is not nearly as good as it's iOS counterpart. 10,000,000 is a touch screen handheld device game - and should not be anything else. It's atrocious to play this with a mouse. It's like night and day. This is a game that relies on quick inputs and mild planning how to arrange the table, and with this clumsy mouse ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that's just not satisfactory.This is one of those games that are perfect in bite sized chunks - for when you are on the train or having a break at the job. If I play for more then 10-20mins in one go I quickly get bored. It's "one of those games".The good music (2 songs...) is still awesome and the gameplay is smooth and dandy on this version. It's just that you cannot get around the deal-breaker here. This should be operated with touch controls. Nothing else. I have not tried, but if I would guess I'd say this game probably is as good as it can be on a iPad.Mechanics....Match 3 or more of the same symbol from the board and you "get" that symbol as a attack on your enemies. A sword for instance is a physical attack. A staff is magical etc. There are symbols you can match and collect too like wood, gold and experience which is used to buy new skills and upgrade your castle/dungeon to improve physical/magical/skill damage output. Oh, and all of this has to go fast because the more you earn the faster the game wants you dead by throwing even more monsters at you. It gets pretty frantic later on. There is more to it but this is the basics.Final verdict....The iOS version 8/10. The Steam version 3/10

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												July 23, 2014 with  1 hour of game play. *        10,000,000 is a match 3, where your are in prison and you need to get a score of 10,000,000 to get free.  I hesitate to call it a story, there is a intro bit that informs on the plot and that’s all you get. You have to level up your character and prison to get multipliers to even think you’ll get that score. There is lot of rpg elements like extra objectives, leveling characters, leveling weapons, and leveling up your prison. Also there is some action elements to go along with the match 3 game play.	The rpg aspects are very minimalist. You don’t level your character automatically as you play. You have to fix up the rooms with stone and wood you have accumulated through matching. Then buy your upgrade with the ingame gold or xp. There is extra objectives, such as ‘use an ax against a monster’ or ‘match 70 in one run’ which adds a bit of twist to the otherwise very grindy gameplay.	It could be considered an action side scroller. Your 2d pixel guy runs at the top of the screen, when you get up to something then you have to match three to get past that obstacle.  There is not anyway of saving up the match. If you get a run of drops it could be bad, first it slows you down as you can not match other stuf while it is falling, and it can clear the board of items you might need later. The match 3 is also a full slider style game play, instead of a single slide, flip, or twist style match 3. The control of the slide is iffy at times, forcing you to waste more time to get past the obstacle because you weren't right over the match.  	10,000,000 is a fast pace hectic match 3 with action-rpg elements. At $4.99 USD it's not a bad price if you like fast pace slide style match 3.  However if you're on the fence I would definitely wait and pick it up when its a buck or as part of a packaged deal. I would give 10,000,000 a 2 out of 5.* I’d have more time on the game but I personally dislike slide style match 3. However I am aware that others do.Also be aware this game is apparently a port of the IOS version. neutral:extra objectives2d side scrolling aspectslider style match 3 game. Pro:rpg elements to level up your character Con:no speed contral, it is a fast pace hectic game. control is irritating (it's a port and it shows at times). there is a lot of grindingmust level up to unlock the ability to buy the rooms. you don’t know what the room is till after you unlock it.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												10,000,000 is a jaunty little puzzle/RPG game that is easy to play and addictively enjoyable. The plot is simple, you wake up in a dungeon cell and as the title of the game implies, you escape the dungeon for good when you score 10 million points in a single run. The game plays like bejeweled in that the player shuffles tiles on a grid by dragging a row or column in order to make 3 symbols match. Successful matches yields attacks, magic, keys, items, gold and materials that you can use to improve your cell, converting it into a base of operations which provides better gear, perks and special potions. The gameplay is easily accessable and there is a method to process of running dungeons that might feel hectic and challenging but never really feels frustrating. An average dungeon run takes only a few minutes but you can run the dungeon as many times as you like before returning to your base. The graphics are simple and have a Commodore 64 quality to them and the chiptune music is nicely composed.10,000,000 is simple, fun, and addictive. Easy to pick up and play, yet challenging when you want it to be. The price is very reasonable and the game is not graphically heavy so you can play it on an older machine. I really enjoyed this game and I think you might too.

												This game is one of those that suprises you by how fun it actually is. On the cover it looks like just another match three game, but once you actually get into action you'll notice it's just so hectic that it's super fun and addictive. And then you notice that  you can actually upgrade your character. To do this you must combine some specific blocks like wood. The upgrades generally provide you more time. So in the beginning a round might take just 15 seconds, but once you're upgraded to the max you'll be in the dungeons for minutes.There's actuallyl not that much grinding if you know what you're doing. Just use the right potions and you'll get an extra amount of wood and stone. Complete the required objectives and you get more skill points. The game never gets frustratingly hard, nor is it too easy. It's just more down to luck of which blocks the game gives you. But once you learn to manage the field properly, even that shouldn't be a big problem.But in the end, the game is just a match 3 game, so if you don't like them, this might not be for you. Although I'm one of those people who doesn't like them, and this was just a blast from the beginning to the end.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												6/10This game earns an "A" for being a clever blend of genres, but a "D" by poorly balancing them it makes the game repetitive, unrewarding, and leaving the player wanting for more.It is a really great concept and fun to play at first. If it was play tested to adjust the poor "grinding" curves, it could be an addictive smash hit.Problems and improvements:1. Resorces... The game has a great concept with harvesting materials to unlock new "shops" to upgrade your character, but wood/stone become obsolete as soon as these shops are all open (which can be done in the first couple hours of game play). Even worse are "Experience Points", which are only spendable at one store. You quickly buy all these upgrades in the first couple hours of gameplay, leaving you a lot of game play earning useless points with nothing to spend them on. Gold is the last to go. After you spend gold upgrading everything to its max, you find that you can't upgrade any farther, and you're still only in the first half of the game.- To fix this, the game needs more options for upgrades with a better price curve to make sure there is always something more to buy or upgrade. The game should be complete or close to completion before you run out of upgrade options in any rpg.2. Effectiveness... Upgrades, even when all are purchased in the first half of the game, do not do enough to make your character feel more powerful or effective. Grinding for upgrades is hard enough, but these upgrades should make even the worst player more effective at the game.Items, if used too early, will be wasted (The same goes for matches that are lined up too early). This is counter-intuitive, since every second counts. When approaching an enemy or chest, it would be great if your continuing multi-combo or clicked item was aimed at them instead of simply lost. Also, while just 4 keys in a row will take care of 2 locks, 4, 5, or more staff/sword tiles do little more than 3 against enemies.3. The Clock... The clock is also your health bar, which is fine and the shield idea makes it work well enough. However, there is far too much working against the clock and not enough helping it. You only gain a small amount of time back after defeating an enemy or unlocking a door/chest (or matching wood/stone with an upgrade), there is a lot that wastes time like combos, which continue to fire off leaving you helpless to act until they are done. These combos, while sometimes helpful, usually just eat time and give little back outside score (which is really only helpful in reaching the overall 10,000,000 to beat the game. Keep in mind, score is NOT cumulative, and is only there to let you know how close you are to getting to the end of the game). Chain combos and 4+ matches should offer a small time bonus as well.4. Luck factor. I have no problem with the Critical hit probability, but the luck of having the right combination of tiles in anything close to the right order to get what you need to match up in time is very random. I've had great runs where I've just had great luck, and blaze through every obstacle, and I've had luck where I lose on the first enemy due to this.5. Gear... There are unlockable potions you an use to trade one thing for another (i.e. 20% of wood/stone earned becomes gold but you earn 0 wood/stone ). These can be turned on and off. The rest of the gear, although upgradable, has no options like many RPGs do. It would be nice if you could buy upgrades for gear, but also swap them out for different effects (i.e. a staff that uses Freeze when it crits, or armor that has a lower effects against close range enemies but blocks ranged attacks, etc.).6. Curve... It could use a difficulty setting. Even if that meant just adjusting time limit, damage effects, etc.Not just that, the overall "Grinding" takes the fun out of the game.Final Verdict:- It's not worth $5. I got my copy on sale for $1 and had cash in my steam wallet from selling trading cards, so... it was basically "free". I wouldn't suggest it for retail price.- If it had the above adjustments made, It would be worth the $5, maybe even $10.- While it has great roots, and is technically a finished game, it really lacks the polish to make it feel like more than a "free to play" you'd find on NewGrounds.6/10

Posted: February 14, 2014
												Very rarely do I "want" to like a game more than I do this one. The style's fun, matching games in general are addictive, and I really do want to keep progressing. But the balance feels wrong and much more often than not the game really frustrates someone just looking for a good time. It's a matching game but if you're not matching the blocks you're supposed to be matching to defeat a monster or unlock a chest or whatever the game is throwing at you, then you die. And you die pretty quickly at that. You can go from full health on a great run to dead in just a few seconds if you haven't matched the tiles that you need. Most of the time you can't find the blocks you need at any given moment, without having cleared other tiles first. The game simply has one block type too many obstructing combo flow. Two of the seven block types have no function in the dungeon crawl except to impede your progress, at any given enemy encounter only two of the blocks might be useful to you. With less than half of the screen being useful and enemies eating your time you'll frequently die in less time it takes to read this review.It wouldn't be so bad if it gave you more time to plan combo chains. Or maybe you could stockpile matched blocks so that items like keys would stay in your invetory for unlocking doors and chests. Instead you can only match blocks at the moment you need them with previous matches disappearing uselessly. Mind you, it has to be at the very moment you need them, if you make the match too fast before the character runs up to the encounter, it also doesn't count wasting valuable blocks.If you somehow ended up becoming a master genius at the game, or if you've grinded enough hours to buy enough perks, it could be great. But the early stages are just no fun and only succeeded in frustrating me. After a while I lose interest in mastery. The game just feels too unfair.

Posted: September 16, 2014
												The game 10,000,000 is really quite fun. If you hate grinding though, STAY SO BLOODY FAR AWAY FROM THIS. This game is a weird mix of bejewelled puzzle action while your character is running through the dungeon slaughtering baddies and opening doors/chests. You match swords to attack, keys to unlock things etc. and that's how your character progresses through this endless dungeon. The entire game is a big'ol grind to the top, running dungeons over and over till you accumulate enough stone/wood/gold/experience to unlock abilities, better gear and better shops. I've only spent a little over an hour when writing this review but if you're looking for a great way to spend your time without breaking the bank here it is!

Posted: August 27, 2014
												10,000,000 is just another matching game, but it is far superior to many of these types of games. For one, there is a story: You are trying to reach a score of 10,000,000 so you can get out of the dungeon/prison environment in which you are in. Simple enough, but this directly affects the gameplay, as at the top of the screen, your character goes through the hallways of the dungeon and has to fight or open doors/chests when you match these tiles. You also match wood and other materials to upgrade things after each quick play-through and armor to protect yourself against your foes.You must complete achievements as well to get higher levels and more of special crystals, which also help you upgrade things (swords, armor, wands, ect.). It gives a very nice variety when you get bored of things like Candy Crush because of no in-app purchases, no limited number of plays, and an actual objective besides beating all the levels (even though there is no levels). The level itself is randomly generated, so you can play as many times as you want and it will almost always be different.In all, it is a very unique puzzle game, and although it is suited best to only 1-3 play-throughs at a time, it is fun for the time you play it. If I had to give a rating, I'd say 8 or 8.5 out of 10.

Posted: February 17, 2014
												Let me just say that I only BARELY recommend this game, and that you would really do yourself a service getting this game while it's on sale or something.Main premise:The point of this game is to reach a score of 10,000,000. This is done by playing a Chuzzle-esque tile match game wherein the tiles you match has an outcome on a dungeon battle. If you by example matches 3 tiles of a sword the guy attacks, 3 keys and you can open chests and doors, 3 wood or stone and you get resources to upgrade later in the game. The game include upgrades, shops, potions, bosses, and a suprisingly big number of valuables (experience, wood, stone, points, and money).Graphics/Sound:The game originated on phones and tablets and you can definitely tell that by a lot of factors. First of all the graphics are in a very heavy and sometimes grating 8-bit style and the sounds and music are entirely in chiptunes. The chiptunes are not bad by any means, but they're put on a short loop and they can get rather repetitive and annoying. It's not a game that needs to be great looking or sound amazing. It does its job, with average success.Gameplay:This is a grinding puzzle game. The main point is to get as far as possible and then retry again and again, until you can buy more upgrades and get a little further into the game until you reach the target score. This is a slow moving process. There really isn't much progress in terms of mechanics. All mechanics of the game is presented in the first 30-45 minutes and then the question is if you actually want to continue doing the same thing for a few hours.The main problem here, is that the game does a very poor job at spacing apart and adding game mechanics as you go along so everything feels fresh. This makes the game stagnate pretty quickly, and you get bored by it easily. You can only play this game in short bursts. This game has two parts to it; the action-puzzle part, and the management/upgrade/RPG-ish part. The first part, is mostly pretty well executed. The tiles do what they do, and you can most of the time tell that a bad run was mostly because that you didn't do well. The game can be a bit unfair in the distribution of different tiles, giving you 3 key tiles in total, when you really need it, but other than that, the nature of the game makes it difficult enough to be challenging, but forgiving enough to not be frustrated.The problems with the game originates from the second part, which is poorly executed. It has the growing of character RPG elements. You know, you start out as a weakling, but then you become stronger and stronger the more you play. Except that this game makes you not feel like progressing at all. It's hard to describe, but I got the same feeling out of playing Defiance. Despite constantly leveling up and progressing to the next level, and fighting tougher enemies and buying more upgrades and improving your various weaponry, it doesn't really feel like you're making a difference. Well, maybe a little, but 2 hours in the game, you don't feel that your character has gotten that much stronger since last. I speculate, that this is because that the core game (the tile game) does not become easier or harder, only the outcome becomes greater.This, together with repetitious gameplay, makes the game stale after longer amounts of play.Story:This game does not really have a story, and for a game like this, it's fine without.Replayability/Concept:I really like the concept, and I feel that with a bit more tweaking and tuning this game could have been a lot more fun and a lot more addictive, which it isn't now, because of the repetitive nature of the game. There is also a bit of originality by this concept, mixing two genres together only really done well in PuzzleQuest.Other than achievements, there is no real reason to start over and try again.Length and fun factor:To be honest, I haven't beaten it yet, but judging by where I am at right now, I estimate a total play time of 3-6 hours.I find the core game (the tile puzzle game) to be very entertaining. It's hectic and it's stimulating, however it's hard finding joy in having to do this, let's be honest here, primitive game over and over again just to feel a bit of evolution and progress.Final Thoughts and judgement:If you are a big puzzle fan, especially of things like Chuzzle, PuzzleQuest, Bejeweled or even Candy Crush, and looking for a simple tile game with even simpler RPG elements over it, then this is recommendable. The puzzle aspect is fun, and if you're into that, the RPG part will not totally ruin it for you. For anyone else this is hard to recommend. For what it's worth I have found entertainment in this game, but some of the core aspects are flawed.If you like puzzle games and you see this on a sale it couldn't hurt to get this (and therefore earning my thumbs up). There are just much better alternatives.

Posted: February 17, 2014
												Let me just say that I only BARELY recommend this game, and that you would really do yourself a service getting this game while it's on sale or something.Main premise:The point of this game is to reach a score of 10,000,000. This is done by playing a Chuzzle-esque tile match game wherein the tiles you match has an outcome on a dungeon battle. If you by example matches 3 tiles of a sword the guy attacks, 3 keys and you can open chests and doors, 3 wood or stone and you get resources to upgrade later in the game. The game include upgrades, shops, potions, bosses, and a suprisingly big number of valuables (experience, wood, stone, points, and money).Graphics/Sound:The game originated on phones and tablets and you can definitely tell that by a lot of factors. First of all the graphics are in a very heavy and sometimes grating 8-bit style and the sounds and music are entirely in chiptunes. The chiptunes are not bad by any means, but they're put on a short loop and they can get rather repetitive and annoying. It's not a game that needs to be great looking or sound amazing. It does its job, with average success.Gameplay:This is a grinding puzzle game. The main point is to get as far as possible and then retry again and again, until you can buy more upgrades and get a little further into the game until you reach the target score. This is a slow moving process. There really isn't much progress in terms of mechanics. All mechanics of the game is presented in the first 30-45 minutes and then the question is if you actually want to continue doing the same thing for a few hours.The main problem here, is that the game does a very poor job at spacing apart and adding game mechanics as you go along so everything feels fresh. This makes the game stagnate pretty quickly, and you get bored by it easily. You can only play this game in short bursts. This game has two parts to it; the action-puzzle part, and the management/upgrade/RPG-ish part. The first part, is mostly pretty well executed. The tiles do what they do, and you can most of the time tell that a bad run was mostly because that you didn't do well. The game can be a bit unfair in the distribution of different tiles, giving you 3 key tiles in total, when you really need it, but other than that, the nature of the game makes it difficult enough to be challenging, but forgiving enough to not be frustrated.The problems with the game originates from the second part, which is poorly executed. It has the growing of character RPG elements. You know, you start out as a weakling, but then you become stronger and stronger the more you play. Except that this game makes you not feel like progressing at all. It's hard to describe, but I got the same feeling out of playing Defiance. Despite constantly leveling up and progressing to the next level, and fighting tougher enemies and buying more upgrades and improving your various weaponry, it doesn't really feel like you're making a difference. Well, maybe a little, but 2 hours in the game, you don't feel that your character has gotten that much stronger since last. I speculate, that this is because that the core game (the tile game) does not become easier or harder, only the outcome becomes greater.This, together with repetitious gameplay, makes the game stale after longer amounts of play.Story:This game does not really have a story, and for a game like this, it's fine without.Replayability/Concept:I really like the concept, and I feel that with a bit more tweaking and tuning this game could have been a lot more fun and a lot more addictive, which it isn't now, because of the repetitive nature of the game. There is also a bit of originality by this concept, mixing two genres together only really done well in PuzzleQuest.Other than achievements, there is no real reason to start over and try again.Length and fun factor:To be honest, I haven't beaten it yet, but judging by where I am at right now, I estimate a total play time of 3-6 hours.I find the core game (the tile puzzle game) to be very entertaining. It's hectic and it's stimulating, however it's hard finding joy in having to do this, let's be honest here, primitive game over and over again just to feel a bit of evolution and progress.Final Thoughts and judgement:If you are a big puzzle fan, especially of things like Chuzzle, PuzzleQuest, Bejeweled or even Candy Crush, and looking for a simple tile game with even simpler RPG elements over it, then this is recommendable. The puzzle aspect is fun, and if you're into that, the RPG part will not totally ruin it for you. For anyone else this is hard to recommend. For what it's worth I have found entertainment in this game, but some of the core aspects are flawed.If you like puzzle games and you see this on a sale it couldn't hurt to get this (and therefore earning my thumbs up). There are just much better alternatives.

Posted: May 6, 2015
 10,000,000 10,000,000 was a very fun game to play, however I couldn't be bothered to play it for too long. Visual: 7/10 I did enjoy the visuals of 10,000,000 however I'm quite sick of the flood of games trying to be retro with pixel-art, so I scored it a 7 because it was neatly done, even if I don't like the art style all that much. Sound: 6/10 The sound is very similar to the art, meaning that there is a retro vibe to it, however I thought the music wasn't produced as well as the visuals were. Most of the time I found myself muting the sound on the game because it became so repetitive. Gameplay: 8/10 The gameplay is like bejeweled but has a twist. The twist is that there is an RPG element to it. The game uses different kinds of attacks and defence stances instead of diamonds and rubies. These attacks and defence stances make the adventurer you control attack or defend enemy attacks, which can be seen in the top corner of the screen. This is very fun, however the game gets very repetitive at a rapid pace. There are some items that you can unlock between dungeons, but there is nothing that switches the gameplay up besides the unlocks. Time/Money: 6/10	I didn't spend as much time as I had anticipated for the money, which is a result of the repetitive gameplay. I usually spend more time than that for a game that cost 5 euros (10,000,000 gave me an hour of gameplay per euro.). I recommend buying this game, but you should probably wait until it goes on sale (assuming you're not a die-hard bejweled fan.).

Posted: February 14, 2014
												6/10This game earns an "A" for being a clever blend of genres, but a "D" by poorly balancing them it makes the game repetitive, unrewarding, and leaving the player wanting for more.It is a really great concept and fun to play at first. If it was play tested to adjust the poor "grinding" curves, it could be an addictive smash hit.Problems and improvements:1. Resorces... The game has a great concept with harvesting materials to unlock new "shops" to upgrade your character, but wood/stone become obsolete as soon as these shops are all open (which can be done in the first couple hours of game play). Even worse are "Experience Points", which are only spendable at one store. You quickly buy all these upgrades in the first couple hours of gameplay, leaving you a lot of game play earning useless points with nothing to spend them on. Gold is the last to go. After you spend gold upgrading everything to its max, you find that you can't upgrade any farther, and you're still only in the first half of the game.- To fix this, the game needs more options for upgrades with a better price curve to make sure there is always something more to buy or upgrade. The game should be complete or close to completion before you run out of upgrade options in any rpg.2. Effectiveness... Upgrades, even when all are purchased in the first half of the game, do not do enough to make your character feel more powerful or effective. Grinding for upgrades is hard enough, but these upgrades should make even the worst player more effective at the game.Items, if used too early, will be wasted (The same goes for matches that are lined up too early). This is counter-intuitive, since every second counts. When approaching an enemy or chest, it would be great if your continuing multi-combo or clicked item was aimed at them instead of simply lost. Also, while just 4 keys in a row will take care of 2 locks, 4, 5, or more staff/sword tiles do little more than 3 against enemies.3. The Clock... The clock is also your health bar, which is fine and the shield idea makes it work well enough. However, there is far too much working against the clock and not enough helping it. You only gain a small amount of time back after defeating an enemy or unlocking a door/chest (or matching wood/stone with an upgrade), there is a lot that wastes time like combos, which continue to fire off leaving you helpless to act until they are done. These combos, while sometimes helpful, usually just eat time and give little back outside score (which is really only helpful in reaching the overall 10,000,000 to beat the game. Keep in mind, score is NOT cumulative, and is only there to let you know how close you are to getting to the end of the game). Chain combos and 4+ matches should offer a small time bonus as well.4. Luck factor. I have no problem with the Critical hit probability, but the luck of having the right combination of tiles in anything close to the right order to get what you need to match up in time is very random. I've had great runs where I've just had great luck, and blaze through every obstacle, and I've had luck where I lose on the first enemy due to this.5. Gear... There are unlockable potions you an use to trade one thing for another (i.e. 20% of wood/stone earned becomes gold but you earn 0 wood/stone ). These can be turned on and off. The rest of the gear, although upgradable, has no options like many RPGs do. It would be nice if you could buy upgrades for gear, but also swap them out for different effects (i.e. a staff that uses Freeze when it crits, or armor that has a lower effects against close range enemies but blocks ranged attacks, etc.).6. Curve... It could use a difficulty setting. Even if that meant just adjusting time limit, damage effects, etc.Not just that, the overall "Grinding" takes the fun out of the game.Final Verdict:- It's not worth $5. I got my copy on sale for $1 and had cash in my steam wallet from selling trading cards, so... it was basically "free". I wouldn't suggest it for retail price.- If it had the above adjustments made, It would be worth the $5, maybe even $10.- While it has great roots, and is technically a finished game, it really lacks the polish to make it feel like more than a "free to play" you'd find on NewGrounds.6/10

Posted: February 14, 2014
												Very rarely do I "want" to like a game more than I do this one. The style's fun, matching games in general are addictive, and I really do want to keep progressing. But the balance feels wrong and much more often than not the game really frustrates someone just looking for a good time. It's a matching game but if you're not matching the blocks you're supposed to be matching to defeat a monster or unlock a chest or whatever the game is throwing at you, then you die. And you die pretty quickly at that. You can go from full health on a great run to dead in just a few seconds if you haven't matched the tiles that you need. Most of the time you can't find the blocks you need at any given moment, without having cleared other tiles first. The game simply has one block type too many obstructing combo flow. Two of the seven block types have no function in the dungeon crawl except to impede your progress, at any given enemy encounter only two of the blocks might be useful to you. With less than half of the screen being useful and enemies eating your time you'll frequently die in less time it takes to read this review.It wouldn't be so bad if it gave you more time to plan combo chains. Or maybe you could stockpile matched blocks so that items like keys would stay in your invetory for unlocking doors and chests. Instead you can only match blocks at the moment you need them with previous matches disappearing uselessly. Mind you, it has to be at the very moment you need them, if you make the match too fast before the character runs up to the encounter, it also doesn't count wasting valuable blocks.If you somehow ended up becoming a master genius at the game, or if you've grinded enough hours to buy enough perks, it could be great. But the early stages are just no fun and only succeeded in frustrating me. After a while I lose interest in mastery. The game just feels too unfair.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Although I haven't completed the game to the full extent, I have started this review. This is one of those simple games that gradually gets harder as your progress through the dungeons, and the game is set in a way where you "bejeweled" your actions. There are many different actions and completeing a dungeon is just carry out 3 challenges in one run. You are able to upgrade your tiles, by that I'm refering to your weaponry, magic, and armor and other perks that you can unlock with the experience you build, and use them to your advantages. Completeing a full dungeon, even after you clear later dungeons, is rather difficult, especially when the boss tends to be a dragon. I wouldn't completely recommend playing it, but if you're willing to spend the money for a game you'll enjoy for a short period of time.., You're welcomed to this game.

												This is a fun timed puzzle game with RPG elements. You create combos of certain items in your playspace to deal with what your character has encountered above your play area. Locked door? Posted: July 6, 2015
												Achievement completion at time of writing: 100%This is a port of the mobile game of the same name. It is a match 3 game where you either slide a row or a column to make matches for whatever is needed at the time. Locked Doors and Chests require keys, Monsters require Swords and Staves, Shields are used for defense, Stars for items to help, and Stone and Wood for building your home base afterwards.The objective is to go as far as you can in a dungeon, and upon failure you take all the resources you gathered to upgrade your home base to allow even further runs. The main goal is to have a total score of over 10,000,000 in one run of a dungeon.It's fun for a few hours, though the game is pretty short. If you can get it cheap, it'll be good value.

Posted: May 6, 2015
 10,000,000 10,000,000 was a very fun game to play, however I couldn't be bothered to play it for too long. Visual: 7/10 I did enjoy the visuals of 10,000,000 however I'm quite sick of the flood of games trying to be retro with pixel-art, so I scored it a 7 because it was neatly done, even if I don't like the art style all that much. Sound: 6/10 The sound is very similar to the art, meaning that there is a retro vibe to it, however I thought the music wasn't produced as well as the visuals were. Most of the time I found myself muting the sound on the game because it became so repetitive. Gameplay: 8/10 The gameplay is like bejeweled but has a twist. The twist is that there is an RPG element to it. The game uses different kinds of attacks and defence stances instead of diamonds and rubies. These attacks and defence stances make the adventurer you control attack or defend enemy attacks, which can be seen in the top corner of the screen. This is very fun, however the game gets very repetitive at a rapid pace. There are some items that you can unlock between dungeons, but there is nothing that switches the gameplay up besides the unlocks. Time/Money: 6/10	I didn't spend as much time as I had anticipated for the money, which is a result of the repetitive gameplay. I usually spend more time than that for a game that cost 5 euros (10,000,000 gave me an hour of gameplay per euro.). I recommend buying this game, but you should probably wait until it goes on sale (assuming you're not a die-hard bejweled fan.).

It's that simple.

Upgrading your damage, magic, armor, and shields as well as the rooms gives you something to look forward too after each run.All of this, coupled with quests, potions, usable items, and a clear motive to GTFO of the dungeon. You'll find yourself losing track of time easily with this puzzler RPG. Fun game. Gameplay: 7/10~The mechanics to the game were done right. A good combination of Puzzler and RPGArt Style: 4/10~Older than classic pixel art. I'm a fan, but there is opportunity here.Music: 5/10~Again an ode to the old days of gaming. But nothing too noteworthy. Good, but not amazing. Difficulty: 3/10~It's a timed puzzler at the core. The RPG elements just make the game easier. Grind out your EXP and Gold and you win.

Posted: May 26, 2015
10,000,000 - in 100 words:It's a tile-matching game. It's a lonely dungeon crawler, never-ending looter. The skill is irrelevant since it is infinite. The more you play...well, the more you play, period. Eventually you'll get out, almost surely. It's just a matter of when, not how and if. Pixels are all over the place, and they are extremely big. You have upgrades, upgrades, and even more upgrades. It's a game you play for five minutes until you realize there are dozens of titles that lie dormant in your library, waiting to be discovered while you waste your time running after ten million points.10,000,000 is......very appropriate if you don't know what to do at work....ugly, extremely ugly, even by retro-pixel-indie standards...mixing two genres, for better or for worse.10,000,000 is not......challenging. It's quite the opposite....leaving your mind for some time, thanks to the music that keeps on repeating forever....a game about numbers, big numbers and scores.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Did you enjoy Puzzle Quest? What about Bejeweled? Or any of the other match-3 puzzle game? What about games where you like watching numbers get bigger? Because I love games like that!10,000,000 is a match-3 puzzle game. The twist is that the timer is your HP. Obstacles (from monsters, to locked doors, to treasure chests) will slow you down. The faster you beat them down, the longer you'll survive. When you do fail, you get to keep the gold that you earned to buy upgrades to make you last a little longer. Once you gain 10,000,000 points, you're home free!

It's a little annoying that you simply can't progress very far until you get enough upgrades no matter how well you play, but it adds to the addictiveness of the game, to complete everything.

The end goal is to reach 10,000,000 points and earn your freedom.If you’re a fan of addictive match-3 games and enjoy some RPG-lite gameplay, you won’t go wrong with this one. Posted: October 30, 2014
												10,000,000 is a fun little casual match three type puzzle game with an RPG theme. In the main part of the screen you have are trying to match 3 or more of a symbol, getting cascades and so on for bonuses. The key twist is that your character needs specific types of matches at certain times - match keys to get through doors or open chests, match swords or staves when you are fighting a monster, and avoid spoiling/using such matches in between while the character is just running along. Meanwhile the other item types you can match give you resources to build up your base, or get bonus items.You also have special subquests to do while running each dungeon, like getting a 5 match, or using only items to kill a monster, etc. It all adds up to give a bit of a strategic element to the basic match three gameplay, and a bit of a fun metagame building up your characters skills and equipments to get more powerful, fighting more dangerous monsters, and eventually achieve the titular 10,000,000 points to win your freedom.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												I got this game on a whim during it's 0.99 cent sale. At the time, I was suffering from a very painful toothache, which was almost dehibilitating. I wanted something I could do that didn't require focus, so I figured I'd try this game. Two things of note; one, my estimate for not requiring focus was completely off-base. Two, I played it from install to near completion in one 5 hour sitting. My toothache was an afterthought. I have no more praiseworthy sentence than that.The concept is simple; it's a match-3 game. Even worse, it's my least favorite kind of match-3 game; a move has to end with 3 or more matching. Nothing akin to, say, Tetris Attack, where you could meticulously plot out an amazing chain, one block move at a time. So why would I recommend this game, even when the first two paragraphs of this review are faintly condemning it?Because it's amazing, that's why. It takes cue from other match-3 games with the simple but addictive gameplay, and then adds it's own finess to the mix. You're exploring a dungeon, and your actions are based on matching tiles. Clear 3 Key tiles to open a lock on a treasure chest, match 3 Sword tiles to swing a sword at an enemy, you get the idea. Run the dungeon as long as you can, slaying enemies, collecting loot, and get as far as you can. Strive for that 10,000,000-point mark.What makes this work so well is it's so frantic. At any given time, you're matching in the grid, while watching your inventory of special, one-shot items, while at the same time plotting for the next encounter. Fighting a dragon? Forget those keys, those wood, you need lots and lots of attacks. At a chest? Those swords do you no good, you're waisting them as only keys will open the locks. The most stressful moments for me were the time between encounters; "I have a five-chain of attacks lined up, I hope it's not a chest or door next..."The game rewards you for each attempt, too. Clearing wood tiles and stone tiles give you those in currency form, you collect gold and EXP from felled monsters and opened chests, and you can refurbish and upgrade your impromptu-home with facilities. Not got enough 'umph' behind your swings? Upgrade your sword at the smithy. It's a repetitive cycle to be sure, but there's no greater joy than building up a horde of gold from your failed runs, pumping up your sword's destructive might, and then laying waste to enemy after enemy with your newfound strength. However, the cycle doesn't continue forever, and once you hit max, that's it. The game will get no easier from there, and all that's left is you and your 10m goal.It's certainly not without it's own flaws though. Early on, the runs are frantic and short. Very, very short. Even in the tutorial run, you won't completely grasp what's going on or even how to plan things out because it's ALREADY OVER. It takes running after running to finally get a feel for the game, and then it goes out of it's way to make you attempt sometimes rediculous maneuvers to advance. These goals include simple things (get a certain score, get a certain amount of EXP), to difficult without planning things (defeat a ranged mob in less than 5 seconds) to downright infuriating (use a scroll to get a triple clear in one shot, seriously? No amount of planning will get you that). These shortcomings I don't nessicarily say are the game's fault, rather, the intencely random nature of this brand of match-3 makes them far harder than need be.When all is said and done, it's welcoming enough for beginners (given some time to adjust), and has enough depth and breadth for hardcore gamers to get a good kick out of it. At 0.99 cents, this was a steal of a game. The full-fledged pricetag of 4.99 is still low for the enjoyment you'll get out of this game. Expect to clock in at least 5 hours of good, solid gameplay before completing, and based on how much the random number god loves (or hates) you, another 3 hours until 100% completion. Even then, it's just fun to do a quick dungeon tromp to burn some time and some dragons.

Posted: February 6, 2014
												This game is just sliding tiles. It tries to seem like more with the RPG elements but that is little more than a skin. The game rewards you for making as many matches as possible, as fast as possible, regardless of what is happening in the top section. Sure, you have to match the right tiles to proceed past each obstacle, but that happens naturally through frantic matching. If you try to play the board strategically you'll find things simply don't happen fast enough and you'll fail the level because time is always ticking down and you HP usually is too. The whole experience feels like it was designed by a gambling cartel trying to get me addicted to slots.The upgrade system was compelling at first but quite quickly became a chore and no longer enhances the experience after a few hours. There is a little strategic freedom in how you spend your resources on upgrades and perks but it really doesn't affect gameplay, it just shifts difficulty from one element to another. There is also an arbitrary wait while upgrades are occurring in which you can't do anything but watch the progress bar. This wait increases with each upgrade for no reason. It isn't long but it is completely unnecessary. The investment type perks are pointless because they effectively just adjust how much grinding is necessary and players won't know how much grinding they want to do until they've missed the opportunity for the investment to be economically viable. I honestly think they game would be better served by automating or removing the entire upgrade system and just implementing a few sliders so players can adjust how good they have to be at tile matching to not lose.The only thing which is still interesting after a few hours is the challenges. There are at most 3 challenges active at any time and new challenges aren't made available until space is made for them by completing an existing challenge. They are things like 'Kill an armored monster with only staves' and 'Open a chest within 5 seconds'. Challenges provide a reason to adjust strategy which helps stop the game becoming stale, however I'm fairly frequently stuck on (a) challenge(s) and the game stops being fun at all. Completing an overly difficult challenge is a relief, not a reward, because a combination of grinding and luck is what gets me there. An option to skip challenges would fix this but might reduce the worth of the challenge system.To put it simply, if you're expecting anything more from the game than a pretty good tile matching time-waster you might be disappointed. I think there is potential in the format but a lot more weight needs to be given to the RPG elements for me to enjoy this as a hybrid puzzle RPG and not just a puzzle game with a guy running at the top of the screen.

Posted: April 3, 2014
												This game is one of those that suprises you by how fun it actually is. On the cover it looks like just another match three game, but once you actually get into action you'll notice it's just so hectic that it's super fun and addictive. And then you notice that  you can actually upgrade your character. To do this you must combine some specific blocks like wood. The upgrades generally provide you more time. So in the beginning a round might take just 15 seconds, but once you're upgraded to the max you'll be in the dungeons for minutes.There's actuallyl not that much grinding if you know what you're doing. Just use the right potions and you'll get an extra amount of wood and stone. Complete the required objectives and you get more skill points. The game never gets frustratingly hard, nor is it too easy. It's just more down to luck of which blocks the game gives you. But once you learn to manage the field properly, even that shouldn't be a big problem.But in the end, the game is just a match 3 game, so if you don't like them, this might not be for you. Posted: February 6, 2015
												This game is very simple, it's your average 3 tiles match game but with some more depth. You got ressources tiles, Woods and Stones, which let's you gain ressources for upgrading your shops. You got keys which let's you open chests and doors. You got bags which will give you a item from time to time. You got attack tiles, Sword and Staff, which make you attack the enemies in front of you and depending of the enemies you're fighting it might be better to use physical attacks (Sword) or magical one (Staff). Shield tiles let you absorb a damage from the enemies. There's also a star tiles which basically can match with any other tiles. With the shop you can upgrade your gears, like your swords so you do more physical damage with sword tiles. You can upgrade your armor so enemies take more time to attack you. You gain experiences so you can unlock skills, like more chances for your magical attacks to make a abnormal status to the enemies. There's also potions that will handicap you so you can gain more points for exemple.The graphics are simple but got charms, the really big selling point to me is the music which is fantastic in this game. So if you like 3 match tiles like I do, this is definetly worth a buy.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												I have a deep and abiding hatred for this game. It could have been so good but...- Most of your combos are either useless or wind up hurting you later.- The alchemy "upgrades" are largely useless.- The multiplier system ensures that you'll have to grind for hours to win.- The achievements have you continue grinding even after beating the game.The core mechanics are good, the music is catchy, but these numerous flaws just bring the game down. If only you could "bank" your bonuses so that they aren't wasted so much, that would be a good first step. As it stands, this is a short diversion and nothing more.

												10 ♥♥♥♥ing million. That's the score you need to get to beat the game. And that's all you gotta do......I might be oversimplifying things a little bit, since it will take you a good couple of hours to beat it (around 7-8h).The game is very easy to understand, you have a guy running on your screen and once you get an obstacle, you have to take care of it. If you have a door, you will have to combine 4 keys, if you have an enemy you can either combine swords or staves. The idea is to never fall behind or you lose.Once you reach preset milestones, you will have the option to play harder levels, that rewards you with higher score multipliers. The higher the level, the higher the score you will get, and the harder the monsters are.This is a game where you will fail 99.9% of the time, and once you get that 10,000,000 score you are likely not to touch this game again, but it's so extremely addictive and at the same time frustrating. After each attempt you can spend your resources (wood, stone and experience) on power ups that will help you get through the levels...Pros:- Very addictive- Decent RPG elementsCons: - Music- Story... or lack of.- Price, the mobile version of this game is much cheaper...7/10

The game can be easily completed in seven hours to get all of the achievements. A drawback is that one does not realise they get their achievements unless they log off the game and then receive them on Steam. The game gets repetitive and leveling the weapon, staff, shield, and skills gets tedious. But it gets challenging when monsters get stronger along with you. Posted: February 28, 2015
												10,000,000? Odd name to say the least, but I'm sure this game will suprise you like it did me. This game is in short a bejeweled spin-off with more action. The way the game work is simple you need to get 10,000,000 score to beat the game and that's the jist of the games core. The game may sound a bit boring with such a simplistic victory condition, but there is more to it than that.The difference of bejeweled and 10,000,000 is the fact you have a hero at the top of the screen you control. Based on the blocks you break you change the outcome of the heros fate by unlocking doors, killing monsters, or just collecting supplies for when you go back to home to spend them on upgrades.There are multiple ways to change the flow of the game. Whether it be with Armor upgrades to reduce damage, Sword upgrades to increase the damage and critical chance on your sword breaks, wand upgrades to increase the damage of your spells and increase the RNG of freezes and poison, and even potions to change the multiplier.I believe that any fan of the puzzle genre should consider picking up this epic and amazing tale of a hero trapped and his only goal is.... 10,000,0009/10

Posted: March 16, 2014
												I'm new to this match-3 game genre and I found the puzzle/rpg hybridness of 10,000,000 very addictive, even too much since I invested so much time on it to reach the 10 million points goal. But at last, freedom!A blocking point for me was that it wasn't very obvious that rooms in addition of being unlocked could also be upgraded, so I got stuck at middle game wondering why I couldn't easily advance anymore as most monsters were kicking my back. Once I figured that out, completing the rest was rather easy. I guess that other people who complained the amount of grinding needed to win the game also incurred in the same problem.This game isn't meant to be finished in a single sitting. It can get a bit repetitive after several tries, but if you limit it to a few ones a time, it will remain a fun game for quite a while.Note that I played it on my PC with a Wacom graphics pen tablet, I guess it isn't as fun and easy to play with a mouse. Actually I imagine it would be a bit frustrating, given the few painful quirks the tile control system has. So, I would not recommend playing this with a mouse unless you seek masochistic challenge.

Posted: March 23, 2013
												This is a puzzle game at heart. If you line up 3 or more coloured tiles they disappear from the grid, they disappear. In much the same fashion as Bejeweled, new tiles then fall down from the top of the grid to fill in the now empty space. The only way this differs from Bejeweled is that instead of swapping two tiles, you instead can drag any row left or right, or any column up or down in its entirety to make a match.However, this is only half of the game, and is frankly the boring bit. Each set of tiles you clear does something different, with the aim of keeping your man running through the dungeon above the board as long as possible. So sword and staff attack monsters, shield defends you, keys open locks, backpack provides items, and wood and stone help you upgrade your base. So this balance of keeping the right tiles on the screen, especially when different monsters are weaker to different attacks, is what keeps this game enthralling.That said, it does have some problems with artificial difficulty. Your health/stamina is represented by how far along the top of the screen your man is. Once this runs out, you have to restart the level for another try at the high score. However, as your man runs through the dungeon, the time it takes to slide backwards along the track  gets shorter and shorter, decreasing your max health no matter how well you are playing. As a result, you often need to start at a later checkpoint to have any chance of progressing to a higher score. I'd have much preferred just a straight run through increasing power/health monsters than a backwards slide down my character's own abilities.So overall:Negatives:The match game is Bejeweled and requires little strategy.Decreasing power through out a run gets on my nerves.Positives:The dungeon combat system is inspired and brings the strategy that Bejeweled lacks.The power increase due to upgrades between runs is well thought through and well paced.If this game had an endless mode, that is a mode where monster health/attack power went up constantly until you die, I'd recommend this in an instant.But without this it lacks replay value as you feel like you're hitting a hard-coded wall instead of the limits of your own ability.So a reasonable game for 3$, is enjoyable, just don't expect too much playtime from it.  7/10

Posted: November 6, 2014
												10,000,000 essentially takes the core gameplay concept of Chuzzle (dragging whole rows and columns to make  a match) and adds classic RPG elements. It's easy to pick up, and it's not TOO hard to put down. If you like slow-paced contemplative tile-matching that make take you an hour to complete a run, this is gonna be a little much for you.It is expected that each run will only last a short time (a minute or two in the early stages), because you are working against the clock. Your hero runs through a long dungeon (displayed at the top of the screen) and meets various obstacles. The type of obstacle will determine what type of match will allow you to advance. The hero runs fast enough to regain time, but the screen keeps scrolling slowly while you are working on an obstacle.Doors and treasure chests require that you match Key tiles. Enemies can be attacked with Sword or Staff tiles. Most enemies will need to be attacked multiple times; they have health bars to let you know how you're doing. You must also endure enemies' attacks, which will reduce your timer (there is no HP, only the timer). Shield tiles can give you damage reduction, and Item tiles can generate useful consumable items for your inventory (one-use weapons and magic spells, keys, food to add time to the clock, etc).You also match Wood and Stone tiles, which accumulate resources that are used back in your hub area in between dungeon runs. You build item shops which allow you to upgrade the effectiveness of each type of tile matches. You'll accumulate Gold and EXP with each dungeon run. Gold can be spent on your various tiered equpiment upgrades, and EXP can be spent on a variety of one-off permanent bonuses (like decreasing the cost of weapon upgrades, or granting bonus time for long combos).You'll also be given up to three objectives to try to complete at the start of each run. These range from "match [X number] of Stone tiles over the course of your run" to "defeat an enemy by only using Items""Beating" the game requires getting a cumulative 10,000,000 points across all your runs, though you can keep playing after that.I've played through the game before, and I'm on my second playthrough now that some new content has been added. It's a nice way to kill a few minutes before I go to work, or a few hours when I get home.

Posted: August 29, 2013
												It's not everyday you see a game named after a number, let alone one hitting 8 digits, so of course my eye was attracted to this pitiular title right off the bat. I've always been a passive fan of board matching games such as Pop Cap's cashcow Bejewled, but 10,000,000 does one of the wierdest genre crossover games I've ever soon - they somehow crammed in a Fantasy-RPG dungeon cralling game into my puzzle game. The tiles you match on the board causes your character to perform an action - locked door in your way? Match key tiles to unlock it! Generic bad guy attacking you? Sword his♥♥♥♥♥or magic his face in by matching sword or rod tiles! It goes deeper than that, but just that alone make it totally worth the low price it is selling for right now. If you're into really fast paced action, get this thing!

Posted: January 24, 2013
												Although it has a lot of things going against it (Match 3 puzzle game, iOS port, etc) this game is loads of fun. Don't be fooled by the store page, this isn't actually an RPG, but simply a match-3 puzzler with RPG elements. While most M3 games have you moving one symbol around in one of 4 directions, this one has you rotating columns/rows to match 3. It takes a bit of getting used to, but well worth it. Most gameplay is spent on the dungeon crawling. You look up on the screen, and match the symbol needed above. eg: If theres a chest, match 3 key symbols.You cannot pass until you match the correct symbol, and theres an advancing wall that kills you (Keep ahead of it!). There are also monsters that you must kill using either Magic or Physical matches (Different monsters have different weaknesses). There are different items you can use too. Overall, a great timewaster/puzzler, but not really a puzzler. 17/20

Posted: March 23, 2013
												This is a puzzle game at heart. If you line up 3 or more coloured tiles they disappear from the grid, they disappear. In much the same fashion as Bejeweled, new tiles then fall down from the top of the grid to fill in the now empty space. The only way this differs from Bejeweled is that instead of swapping two tiles, you instead can drag any row left or right, or any column up or down in its entirety to make a match.However, this is only half of the game, and is frankly the boring bit. Each set of tiles you clear does something different, with the aim of keeping your man running through the dungeon above the board as long as possible. So sword and staff attack monsters, shield defends you, keys open locks, backpack provides items, and wood and stone help you upgrade your base. So this balance of keeping the right tiles on the screen, especially when different monsters are weaker to different attacks, is what keeps this game enthralling.That said, it does have some problems with artificial difficulty. Your health/stamina is represented by how far along the top of the screen your man is. Once this runs out, you have to restart the level for another try at the high score. However, as your man runs through the dungeon, the time it takes to slide backwards along the track  gets shorter and shorter, decreasing your max health no matter how well you are playing. As a result, you often need to start at a later checkpoint to have any chance of progressing to a higher score. I'd have much preferred just a straight run through increasing power/health monsters than a backwards slide down my character's own abilities.So overall:Negatives:The match game is Bejeweled and requires little strategy.Decreasing power through out a run gets on my nerves.Positives:The dungeon combat system is inspired and brings the strategy that Bejeweled lacks.The power increase due to upgrades between runs is well thought through and well paced.If this game had an endless mode, that is a mode where monster health/attack power went up constantly until you die, I'd recommend this in an instant.But without this it lacks replay value as you feel like you're hitting a hard-coded wall instead of the limits of your own ability.So a reasonable game for 3$, is enjoyable, just don't expect too much playtime from it.  7/10

Posted: November 6, 2016
												A rather simple match-3 with simple Rogue "lite" elements and a simple plot, Notice the pattern yet?You awake in a stone chamber with a bunch of doors, all but one is locked off, entering the big door causes the game to begin. The game follows a runner format type of game, up top is your dude running from left to right, he'll run until he hits a obstacle (Monster or a lock) and you match what you need from the bottom puzzle board.Sword & staves do damage while the keys unlock locks, also in the board are armor tiles, item tiles and resource tiles. You keep this up until you lose by the screen catching up with you, which then causes you to awake back in the stone chamber.You can spend the resources you find to open and upgrade the rooms which in turn boost your abillity to play the game,rinse & repeat until you get 10,000,000 score and you win the game, simple.There are milestones and challenges to complete that give you some resources and multipliers adding your end goal.All in all it's a short but addicting match-3, nothing amazing but simply solid in its execution.

Posted: July 11, 2016
												Well, this game was a damn pleasant surprise. It had been on my radar for a few years but every time I looked it up I left mostly unimpressed. Mostly, it was because I preferred swap match 3 games to sliding match 3 games, and I assumed the RPG elements would be gimmicky or hard to keep track of.I recently picked up the game in a Humble Bundle (along with its sequel, You Must Build a Boat) and this was an unexpected pleasure. The RPG and match-3 gameplay melds together brilliantly, with situationally important icons adding a simplistic complexity to the old genre. The soundtrack is catchy, and the progression feels natural and well-paced. I'm glad I own this!

Pros: -Tried and true match-three system.-Unobtrusive soundtrack.-Unobtrusive graphics.-No obnoxious in-game purchases.Cons:-Unimpressive soundtrack.-Unimpressive graphics.-Gameplay is an endless grind.Overall: 4.5/10, a hair below average. If you're looking for a great match-three puzzler... eh, you can do better. That said, if you're a parent, I'd bump it up to 6/10 just because Little Johnny and Susie can't rack up ten thousand dollars on power ups.

Posted: July 8, 2016
If Candy Crush was an RPG it would be thisInitially when I started this game I instantly thought "oh look another match 3 game, this will be fun like 10 minutes" but then I started to realize it was kinda fun. The challenges or "quests" for each level kept me playing beyond the first 10 minutes and as I went up through the first few levels it got harder and I started to get stuck till I realized the boarded doors were not different levels but upgrade stations which is where the RPG elements come into it. Progression is the big thing that will keep you playing the game, upgrading your sword, staff and armor helps you get through later levels as they get harder.While it does play just like a matching game similar to games like candy crush the RPG elements set it apart enough to almost not resemble games of the same genre. In this game your goal is to get to 10,000,000 points but points are not achieved making matches but by moving forward in the dungeon. This is where different types of matches are important for facing different types of challenges like opening doors, chests or killing enemies. Standing still will push you back so preparing and understanding your board is important to success which means you can't just match everything in sight and do well.The game relies on quick reaction in both eye and mind between the board and the RPG going on above as well as a little luck and random dragging when your board starts to get filled with the things you don't want.7.3/10- Addictive and challenging RPG inspired match-three puzzle game

												Just addicting enough that it doesn't trip over its own feet, a perfectly aggravating blend of dungeon running and fast-paced puzzle logic mixed with the feeling you get from performing daily quests. If you're a fan of grinding, this game has unlocks for days. How fast you progress depends mostly on how quick your mind is but wise use of potions and resources are also factors.Pros:-One more run for that new swordCons:-You WILL be doing the same thing over and over again.If you understand what you're getting into, definitely grab this game up.

Posted: August 8, 2015
												Shatter tiles and walk thru long corridors in Ten Million! 10,000,000 is a match 3 puzzle game dressed up with RPG elements. The tiles you match correspond to your characters actions as he travels the games "dungeon", i.e. match keys to unlock doors. There are also stone and wood tiles which allow you to upgrade your home base, which allows you to upgrade your character between runs; and a couple of different attacks to help with monsters. It's very subject to the whims of the RNG so some runs can end very quickly whilst others will have everything fall into place with little effort. Pun not intended. The graphics are a little rough around the edges but do their job and the same could be said of the audio, all in all this is a cheap time waster that is sometimes fun, sometimes frustrating. I give it 4/10 and wouldn’t want to pay more than $2 for it but it has its charm and a nice RPG gimmick to separate it from other match 3's. Good - Lots of gameplay - Fun, when you get on a good runBad - Graphics are simple and unpolished. They do the job, but thats about all they do - A little too luck dependent for me - GrindyRecommended only if you are a huge fan of this type of game 3/5

Posted: January 3, 2016
												There aren’t too many puzzle games that do what this one does. While it at first might seem like a simple match-4 game with some fantasy elements thrown in, there is so much more below the surface. 10,000,000 is a puzzle game that focuses on upgradeable equipment, dungeon running, resource collecting, and finishing quests. Now, I don’t know about you, but there aren’t too many puzzle games that come to mind that can check off those same boxes. This game does something very special: it makes you want to solve puzzles, not just to get to the next level, but to progress in every sense of the term. Your character will gain access to better weapons, shields, and even potions which help all help customize the experience. 10,000,000 does all of this while being wrapped in a very basic pixel-art shell with music that is guaranteed to be stuck in your head for days.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												10,000,000 is a match-three style adventure game with RPG elements. The gameplay is very simple and tactics are similarly uncomplicated. Your character runs along a dungeon hall and encounters various monsters, locked doors or locked chests. It's up to you to slide either columns or rows of symbols on a grid to match at least three of the same symbol to perform an action. The more symbols you match, the more effective the action. Where this differs from the classic match 3 experience is that you must defeat whatever obstacle is in your path with the appropriate matched items. You have to match keys to unlock locks and defeat monsters with swords or wands. Meanwhile you also try to manage your board, gather resources for improvements to equipment and ultimately hit the magic score.All in all, gameplay is smooth, game is fun. Get it.I have 10,000,000 on both PC and Android platforms and while I definitely can recommend picking it up either way, my prefered platform is actually Android.
